title: A note on Refracted Skew Brownian Motion with an application

sections.text:
## - Zaniar Ahmadi *
Mathematics and Statistics Department
Concordia University
Montreal, Canada
zaniar.ahmadi@concordia.ca Xiaowen Zhou ${ }^{* *}$
Mathematics and Statistics Department
Concordia University
Montreal, Canada
xiaowen.zhou@concordia.ca April 8, 2025

#### Abstract

For refracted skew Brownian motion (skew Brownian motion with two-valued drift), adopting a perturbation approach we find expressions of its potential densities. As applications, we recover its transition density and study its long-time asymptotic behaviors. In addition, we also compare with previous results on transition densities for skew Brownian motions. We propose two approaches for generating quasi-random samples by approximating the cumulative distribution function and discuss their risk measurement application.


Keywords Skew Brownian motion $\cdot$ Potential density $\cdot$ Transition density $\cdot$ Stochastic differential equation $\cdot$ Quasi-random sampling $\cdot$ Risk measurement

## I Introduction

Skew Brownian motion (SBM for short) was first introduced by Itô and McKean in 1965 in Section two of their book [22]. In 1978 Walsh [32] proposed a path construction of skew Brownian motion and found an expression for the transition density of skew Brownian motion. Harrison and Shepp [19] showed that skew Brownian motion is the weak limit of a symmetric random walk on the integers with modified behavior at the origin, and also proved that it is the unique strong solution to a stochastic differential equation driven by Brownian motion together with a singular drift of its local time at 0 . In 1984 Le Gall [27] further established the existence and pathwise uniqueness of strong solutions to a more general stochastic differential equation with a general diffusion coefficient involving local times at different levels. Appuhamillage et al. in [2] for the first time analyzed the skew Brownian motion with one drift and provided the joint distribution of key functionals of skew Brownian motion. We refer to Lejay in [28] for a review of earlier work related to skew Brownian motion.

Skew Brownian motion is a versatile concept with applications spanning diverse domains. Notably, in mathematical finance, it serves as a fundamental tool for option pricing, as evidenced by studies such as those by Corns and Satchell. [11], Wang et al. [33], Gairat and Shcherbakov [15], and Zhu and He [35]. Additionally, it finds applications in the interest rate and intensity modeling, with notable contributions from Jarrow et al. [23], Duffie and Singleton. [13], and Decamps et al. [12]. Calibrating skew Brownian motion parameters has been the subject of intensive research. Bardou and Martinez [6] introduced a statistical estimator for calibrating the coefficients of a skewed process in the case in which it is reflected over a bounded interval. Bai et al. [5] advocated for a Bayesian approach to estimate the skew coefficient and skew level of the skew Ornstein-Uhlenbeck (OU) process, and Lajay and Mazzonetto [29] proposed the use of Maximum Likelihood Estimators to calibrate the parameters of a skew Brownian motion. Furthermore, skew Brownian motion is instrumental in addressing dispersion in heterogeneous media. Noteworthy contributions

    ${ }^{\dagger}$ Corresponding author

include works by Freidlin and Sheu [14], Ramirez [31], and Appuhamillage et al. [2]. Moreover, it proves invaluable in modeling diffusion problems with spatially discontinuous diffusion coefficients, as highlighted in studies by Zhang [34] and Ascione et al. [3].
It is an interesting problem to identify probability laws for solutions to singular SDEs. The trivariate density of Brownian Motion and its local and occupation time were obtained in Karatzas and Shreve [24] and applied to problems of stochastic control. An expression for transition density of skew Brownian motion was first found by Walsh [32]. Berezin and Zayats [7] found an expression of transition density for skew Brownian motion with alternating drift (or skew Caughey-Dieness process as mentioned in their paper) in [7]. Gairat and Schenrbakov [15] used an approximation method for obtaining the joint distribution of both Brownian motion and skew Brownian motion with two-valued drift and their functionals. To enhance precision, the researchers approximate skew Brownian motion with two-valued drift using a discrete Markov chain. Except at skew level zero, this Markov chain evolves in the same way as a simple random walk with unit jumps. Notably, the authors employ a complex and lengthy methodology to determine transition probabilities. However, significant details about this method are excluded from their explanation. The same authors obtained the probability density of skew Brownian motion with alternating drifts in Gairat and Schenrbakov [16]. In 2023, Borodin [8] found the potential measure of skew Brownian motion with two-valued drift using the Laplace transform method to solve the associated partial differential equation, and calculated the distributions of integral its functionals with respect to spatial variable of local time.
In this paper, we find expressions of potential measures for refracted skew Brownian motion (RSBM) and then obtain an expression for transition density by inverting the Laplace transform. Applying the above results we further discuss the asymptotic behaviors of the skew Brownian motion with two-valued drift. To this end we adopt a new perturbation approach of Chen et al. [10] that is different from those in [8] and [15]. More precisely, we take use of the solution of RSBM in Gao et al. [17] and the previous results on the potential measure of Brownian motion with drift. We then discuss the long-term behaviors of the skew Brownian motion such as the stationary density. We also compare our results with previous similar results on Skew Brownian motions.
The rest of the paper is arranged as follows. In Section II we introduce the skew Brownian motion with two-valued drift and its exit problems. In Section III we derive expressions for the potential measures applying solutions to the exit problems together with a perturbation approach. In Section IV we invert the Laplace transform to find explicit formulas for the transition densities. In Section V we discuss the limiting behaviors of the refracted skew-Brownian motion. Finally, In section VI we propose two approaches to estimate the cumulative distribution function to generate quasi-random samples of SBM. These approximations are also used to estimate two conventional risk metrics, Value at Risk (VaR) and Conditional Value at Risk (CVaR).

# II Refracted Skew Brownian Motion and its exit problems 

In this section, we consider a refracted skew Brownian motion, $X=\left(X_{t}\right)_{t \geq 0}$, defined on a filtered probability space $\left(\mathcal{F},\left(\mathcal{F}_{t}\right)_{t \geq 0}, \mathbb{P}\right)$, which is the pathwise unique solution to SDE

$$
X_{t}=X_{0}+B_{t}+\beta L^{X}(t, a)+\mu_{+} \int_{0}^{t} \mathbb{1}_{\left\{X_{s}>a\right\}} \mathrm{d} s+\mu_{-} \int_{0}^{t} \mathbb{1}_{\left\{X_{s}<a\right\}} \mathrm{d} s, \quad t \geq 0
$$

where $X_{0}, \mu_{+}, \mu_{-} \in \mathbb{R}$ and $a$ is skew level, and $\beta \in(-1,1), B$ denotes a standard Brownian motion and

$$
L^{X}(t, a):=\lim _{\epsilon \rightarrow 0^{+}} \frac{1}{2 \epsilon} \operatorname{Leb}\left(s \leq t:\left|X_{s}-a\right| \leq \epsilon\right)
$$

denotes the symmetric local time process for $X$ at level $a$ up to time $t \in \mathbb{R}_{+}$, see e.g. Le Gall [27] for existence and uniqueness of solution to (1).
Remark 1. Note that for $\sigma>0, Y$ solves SDE

$$
Y_{t}=Y_{0}+\sigma B_{t}+\beta \sigma L^{Y}(t, \sigma a)+\sigma \mu_{+} \int_{0}^{t} \mathbb{1}_{\left\{Y_{s}>\sigma a\right\}} \mathrm{d} s+\sigma \mu_{-} \int_{0}^{t} \mathbb{1}_{\left\{Y_{s}<\sigma a\right\}} \mathrm{d} s
$$

if and only if $X_{t}:=Y_{t} / \sigma$ solves $S D E$

$$
X_{t}=Y_{0} / \sigma+B_{t}+\beta L^{X}(t, a)+\mu_{+} \int_{0}^{t} \mathbb{1}_{\left\{X_{s}>a\right\}} \mathrm{d} s+\mu_{-} \int_{0}^{t} \mathbb{1}_{\left\{X_{s}<a\right\}} \mathrm{d} s
$$

For a boundary $y \in \mathbb{R}$, define the first hitting time of the boundary $y$ for the stochastic process $X_{t}$ to be

$$
\tau_{y}:=\inf \left\{t \geq 0: X_{t}=y\right\}
$$

with the convention $\inf \emptyset=\infty$. We denote the Laplace transform of $\tau_{y}$ as $\mathbb{E}_{x}\left[e^{-q \tau_{y}}\right]$ for a fixed $q \geq 0$. For any interval $[y, z]$, where $x, y, z \in \mathbb{R}$ and $y \leq x<z$, we denote the first hitting time for the lower barrier $y$ and upper barrier $z$ for the stochastic process $\left\{X_{t}\right\}_{\{t \geq 0\}}$ as $\tau_{y}$ and $\tau_{z}$, respectively. Then define the first exit time of the interval $(y, z)$ by

$$
\tau_{y, z}:=\tau_{y} \wedge \tau_{z}=\min \left\{\tau_{y}, \tau_{z}\right\}
$$

Moreover, the Laplace transform of $\tau_{y}$ for $\tau_{y}<\tau_{z}$ is expressed as $\mathbb{E}_{x}\left[e^{-q \tau_{y}} ; \tau_{y}<\tau_{z}\right]$. The Laplace transform of $\tau_{z}$ for $\tau_{z}<\tau_{y}$ is expressed as $\mathbb{E}_{x}\left[e^{-q \tau_{z}} ; \tau_{z}<\tau_{y}\right]$. It can be interpreted as the Laplace transform of the time of ruin before reaching the lower barrier $y$ and plays a key role in the problems of negative duration and occupation time.
Note that $\operatorname{SDE}$ (1) has a pathwise unique solution. To obtain the Laplace transform of some exit times, we first need to find the general solutions $g_{1, q}(x)$ and $g_{2, q}(x)$ in $C(\mathbb{R}) \cap C^{2}(\mathbb{R} \backslash\{a\})$ to the following equation:

$$
\frac{1}{2} g^{\prime \prime}(x)+\mu_{+} \mathbb{1}_{\{x>a\}} g^{\prime}(x)+\mu_{-} \mathbb{1}_{\{x<a\}} g^{\prime}(x)=q g(x)
$$

with $(1+\beta) g^{\prime}\left(a^{+}\right)=(1-\beta) g^{\prime}\left(a^{-}\right)$for $\beta \in(-1,1)$ and $q \geq 0$.
Let $\delta^{-}=\sqrt{\mu_{-}^{2}+2 q}$, and $\rho_{1}^{-}=-\left(\mu_{-}+\delta^{-}\right)$and $\rho_{2}^{-}=-\mu_{-}+\delta^{-}$be the root of equation $\frac{1}{2} x^{2}+\mu_{-} x-q=0$, where $\rho_{1}^{-}<0<\rho_{2}^{-}$. Beside that, let $\delta^{+}=\sqrt{\mu_{+}^{2}+2 q}$, and $\rho_{1}^{+}=-\left(\mu_{+}+\delta^{+}\right)$and $\rho_{2}^{+}=-\mu_{+}+\delta^{+}$be the root of equation $\frac{1}{2} x^{2}+\mu_{+} x-q=0$, where $\rho_{1}^{+}<0<\rho_{2}^{+}$. Let

$$
g_{1, q}(x)=e^{\rho_{1}^{+}(x-a)} \mathbf{1}_{\{x>a\}}+\left(c_{1}(q) e^{\rho_{2}^{-}(x-a)}+\left(1-c_{1}(q)\right) e^{\rho_{1}^{-}(x-a)}\right) \mathbf{1}_{\{x \leq a\}}
$$

and

$$
g_{2, q}(x)=\left(\left(1-c_{2}(q)\right) e^{\rho_{2}^{+}(x-a)}+c_{2}(q) e^{\rho_{1}^{+}(x-a)}\right) \mathbf{1}_{\{x>a\}}+e^{\rho_{2}^{-}(x-a)} \mathbf{1}_{\{x \leq a\}}
$$

where

$$
c_{1}(q)=\frac{(1+\beta) \rho_{1}^{+}-(1-\beta) \rho_{1}^{-}}{(1-\beta)\left(\rho_{2}^{-}-\rho_{1}^{-}\right)}
$$

and

$$
c_{2}(q)=\frac{(1+\beta) \rho_{2}^{+}-(1-\beta) \rho_{2}^{-}}{(1+\beta)\left(\rho_{2}^{+}-\rho_{1}^{+}\right)}
$$

The following two theorems are presented by Gao et al. [17] and serve as the foundation for derivations in the preceding sections.
Theorem 1. For $x, y, z \in \mathbb{R}$ and $y \leq x<z$, we have

$$
\mathbb{E}_{x}\left[e^{-q \tau_{z}} ; \tau_{z}<\tau_{y}\right]=\frac{w(x, y)}{w(z, y)}
$$

and

$$
\mathbb{E}_{x}\left[e^{-q \tau_{y}} ; \tau_{y}<\tau_{z}\right]=\frac{w(x, z)}{w(y, z)}
$$

where

$$
w(x, y):=g_{2, q}(x) g_{1, q}(y)-g_{1, q}(x) g_{2, q}(y)
$$

Theorem 2. For $x, r \in \mathbb{R}$ and $x \geq r$,

$$
\mathbb{E}_{x}\left[e^{-q \tau_{r}}\right]=e^{\rho_{1}^{+}(x-r)} \mathbf{1}_{\{r>a\}}+\frac{g_{1, q}(x)}{c_{1}(q) e^{\rho_{2}^{-}(r-a)}+\left(1-c_{1}(q)\right) e^{\rho_{1}^{-}(r-a)}} \mathbf{1}_{\{r \leq a\}}
$$

and for $x<r$,

$$
\mathbb{E}_{x}\left[e^{-q \tau_{r}}\right]=e^{\rho_{2}^{-}(x-r)} \mathbf{1}_{\{r \leq a\}}+\frac{g_{2, q}(x)}{\left(1-c_{2}(q)\right) e^{\rho_{2}^{+}(r-a)}+c_{2}(q) e^{\rho_{1}^{+}(r-a)}} \mathbf{1}_{\{r>a\}}
$$

# III Potential measures of RSBM 

Throughout this paper, we assume $e_{q}$ has an exponential distribution with intensity $q$ that is independent of $X_{t}$.
Using the results of Theorem 1 and Theorem 2, the memoryless property of exponential distribution, and the Markov property of skew Brownian motion, we can derive the following theorem.
Theorem 3. The potential measure of the refracted skew Brownian motion $X_{t}$ with skew level $a=0$ and starting point $x=0$ is given by:

$$
\mathbb{P}\left(X_{e_{q}} \in \mathrm{~d} y\right)=\left\{\begin{array}{l}
\frac{2(1+\beta) q}{(1+\beta) \mu_{+}-(1-\beta) \mu_{-}+(1+\beta) \sqrt{\mu_{+}^{2}+2 q+(1-\beta) \sqrt{\mu_{-}^{2}+2 q}} e^{\left(\mu_{+}-\sqrt{\mu_{+}^{2}+2 q}\right) y} \mathrm{~d} y, \quad y>0 \\
\frac{2(1-\beta) q}{(1+\beta) \mu_{+}-(1-\beta) \mu_{-}+(1+\beta) \sqrt{\mu_{+}^{2}+2 q+(1-\beta) \sqrt{\mu_{-}^{2}+2 q}} e^{\left(\mu_{-}+\sqrt{\mu_{-}^{2}+2 q}\right) y} \mathrm{~d} y, \quad y<0
\end{array}\right.
$$

Proof. Let $X_{t}^{1}=\mu_{+} t+B_{t}$ be a Brownian motion and let $\tau_{x}^{1}$ be the first hitting time of process $X_{t}^{1}$. For $0<\epsilon<y$, by the Markov property and the memoryless property,

$$
\begin{aligned}
\mathbb{P}\left(X_{e_{q}} \in \mathrm{~d} y\right) & =\mathbb{P}\left(\tau_{\epsilon}<e_{q}, X_{e_{q}} \in \mathrm{~d} y\right) \\
& =\mathbb{P}\left(\tau_{\epsilon}<e_{q}\right) \mathbb{P}_{\epsilon}\left(X_{e_{q}} \in \mathrm{~d} y\right) \\
& =\mathbb{E} e^{-q \tau_{\epsilon}}\left(\mathbb{P}_{\epsilon}\left(\tau_{0}<e_{q}, X_{e_{q}} \in \mathrm{~d} y\right)+\mathbb{P}_{\epsilon}\left(e_{q}<\tau_{0}, X_{e_{q}} \in \mathrm{~d} y\right)\right) \\
& =\mathbb{E} e^{-q \tau_{\epsilon}}\left(\mathbb{E}_{\epsilon} e^{-q \tau_{0}} \mathbb{P}\left(X_{e_{q}} \in \mathrm{~d} y\right)+\mathbb{P}_{\epsilon}\left(e_{q}<\tau_{0}^{1}, X_{e_{q}}^{1} \in \mathrm{~d} y\right)\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

Solving the above equation we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
\int_{0}^{\infty} q e^{-q t} \mathbb{P}\left(X_{t} \in \mathrm{~d} y\right) \mathrm{d} t & =\mathbb{P}\left(X_{e_{q}} \in \mathrm{~d} y\right) \\
& =\lim _{\epsilon \rightarrow 0^{+}} \frac{\mathbb{E} e^{-q \tau_{\epsilon}} \mathbb{P}_{\epsilon}\left(e_{q}<\tau_{0}^{1}, X_{e_{q}}^{1} \in \mathrm{~d} y\right)}{1-\mathbb{E} e^{-q \tau_{\epsilon}} \mathbb{E}_{\epsilon} e^{-q \tau_{0}}} \\
& =\lim _{\epsilon \rightarrow 0^{+}} \frac{\mathbb{E} e^{-q \tau_{\epsilon}}\left(\mathbb{P}_{\epsilon}\left(X_{e_{q}}^{1} \in \mathrm{~d} y\right)-\mathbb{P}_{\epsilon}\left(e_{q}>\tau_{0}^{1}\right) \mathbb{P}\left(X_{e_{q}}^{1} \in \mathrm{~d} y\right)\right)}{1-\mathbb{E} e^{-q \tau_{\epsilon}} \mathbb{E}_{\epsilon} e^{-q \tau_{0}}} \\
& =\lim _{\epsilon \rightarrow 0^{+}} \frac{\mathbb{E} e^{-q \tau_{\epsilon}}\left(\mathbb{P}_{\epsilon}\left(X_{e_{q}}^{1} \in \mathrm{~d} y\right)-\mathbb{E}_{\epsilon} e^{-q \tau_{0}} \mathbb{P}\left(X_{e_{q}}^{1} \in \mathrm{~d} y\right)\right)}{1-\mathbb{E} e^{-q \tau_{\epsilon}} \mathbb{E}_{\epsilon} e^{-q \tau_{0}}} \\
& =\lim _{\epsilon \rightarrow 0^{+}} \frac{\mathbb{P}_{\epsilon}\left(X_{e_{q}}^{1} \in \mathrm{~d} y\right)-e^{\rho_{1}^{+} \epsilon} \mathbb{P}\left(X_{e_{q}}^{1} \in \mathrm{~d} y\right)}{\left(1-c_{2}(q)\right) e^{\rho_{2}^{+} \epsilon}+\left(c_{2}(q)-1\right) e^{\rho_{1}^{+} \epsilon}} \quad l^{\prime} \text { Hôpital's rule } \\
& =\lim _{\epsilon \rightarrow 0^{+}} \frac{d}{d \epsilon} \mathbb{P}_{\epsilon}\left(X_{e_{q}}^{1} \in \mathrm{~d} y\right)-\rho_{1}^{+} e^{\rho_{1}^{+} \epsilon} \mathbb{P}\left(X_{e_{q}}^{1} \in \mathrm{~d} y\right)}{\left(1-c_{2}(q)\right) \rho_{2}^{+} e^{\rho_{2}^{+} \epsilon}+\left(c_{2}(q)-1\right) \rho_{1}^{+} e^{\rho_{1}^{+} \epsilon}} \\
& =\lim _{\epsilon \rightarrow 0^{+}} \frac{\frac{q}{d^{+}}\left(-\mu_{+}+\delta^{+}\right) e^{\left(\mu_{+}-\delta^{+}\right)(y-\epsilon)}-\rho_{1}^{+} e^{\rho_{1}^{+} \epsilon} \frac{q}{d^{+} e^{\left(\mu_{+}-\delta^{+}\right) y}}}{(1-c_{2}(q)) \rho_{2}^{+} e^{\rho_{2}^{+} \epsilon}+\left(c_{2}(q)-1\right) \rho_{1}^{+} e^{\rho_{1}^{+} \epsilon}} \mathrm{~d} y \\
& =\frac{\frac{q}{d^{+}}\left(\rho_{2}^{+}-\rho_{1}^{+}\right) e^{\left(\mu_{+}-\delta^{+}\right) y}}{\left(1-c_{2}(q)\right)\left(\rho_{2}^{+}-\rho_{1}^{+}\right)} \mathrm{d} y \\
& =\frac{q}{\delta^{+}\left(1-c_{2}(q)\right)} e^{\left(\mu_{+}-\delta^{+}\right) y} \mathrm{~d} y
\end{aligned}
$$

where $\mathbb{P}\left(X_{e_{q}}^{1} \in \mathrm{~d} y\right)=\frac{q}{d^{+}} e^{\left(\mu_{+}-\delta^{+}\right) y} \mathrm{~d} y$. Substituting $\delta^{+}$and $c_{2}(q)$,

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \int_{0}^{\infty} q e^{-q t} \mathbb{P}\left(X_{t} \in \mathrm{~d} y\right) \mathrm{d} t= \\
& \frac{2(1+\beta) q}{(1+\beta) \mu_{+}-(1-\beta) \mu_{-}+(1+\beta) \sqrt{\mu_{+}^{2}+2 q+(1-\beta) \sqrt{\mu_{-}^{2}+2 q}} e^{\left(\mu_{+}-\sqrt{\mu_{+}^{2}+2 q}\right) y} \mathrm{~d} y
\end{aligned}
$$

When $y<\epsilon<0$, for $\epsilon<0$. Let $X_{t}^{2}=\mu_{-} t+B_{t}$ be a Brownian motion and let $\tau_{x}^{2}$ be the hitting time of process $X_{t}^{2}$. For $y<\epsilon<0$, by the Markov property and the memoryless property,

$$
\begin{aligned}
\mathbb{P}\left(X_{e_{q}} \in \mathrm{~d} y\right) & =\mathbb{P}\left(\tau_{\epsilon}<e_{q}, X_{e_{q}} \in \mathrm{~d} y\right) \\
& =\mathbb{P}\left(\tau_{\epsilon}<e_{q}\right) \mathbb{P}_{\epsilon}\left(X_{e_{q}} \in \mathrm{~d} y\right) \\
& =\mathbb{E} e^{-q \tau_{\epsilon}}\left(\mathbb{P}_{\epsilon}\left(\tau_{0}<e_{q}, X_{e_{q}} \in \mathrm{~d} y\right)+\mathbb{P}_{\epsilon}\left(e_{q}<\tau_{0}, X_{e_{q}} \in \mathrm{~d} y\right)\right) \\
& =\mathbb{E} e^{-q \tau_{\epsilon}}\left(\mathbb{E}_{\epsilon} e^{-q \tau_{0}} \mathbb{P}\left(X_{e_{q}} \in \mathrm{~d} y\right)+\mathbb{P}_{\epsilon}\left(e_{q}<\tau_{0}^{2}, X_{e_{q}}^{2} \in \mathrm{~d} y\right)\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

Solving the above equation we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
\int_{0}^{\infty} q e^{-q t} \mathbb{P}\left(X_{t} \in \mathrm{~d} y\right) \mathrm{d} t & =\mathbb{P}\left(X_{e_{q}} \in \mathrm{~d} y\right) \\
& =\lim _{\epsilon \rightarrow 0^{-}} \frac{\mathbb{E} e^{-q \tau_{\epsilon}} \mathbb{P}_{\epsilon}\left(e_{q}<\tau_{0}^{2}, X_{e_{q}}^{2} \in \mathrm{~d} y\right)}{1-\mathbb{E} e^{-q \tau_{\epsilon}} \mathbb{E}_{\epsilon} e^{-q \tau_{0}}} \\
& =\lim _{\epsilon \rightarrow 0^{-}} \frac{\mathbb{E} e^{-q \tau_{\epsilon}}\left(\mathbb{P}_{\epsilon}\left(X_{e_{q}}^{2} \in \mathrm{~d} y\right)-\mathbb{P}_{\epsilon}\left(e_{q}>\tau_{0}^{2}\right) \mathbb{P}\left(X_{e_{q}}^{2} \in \mathrm{~d} y\right)\right)}{1-\mathbb{E} e^{-q \tau_{\epsilon}} \mathbb{E}_{\epsilon} e^{-q \tau_{0}}} \\
& =\lim _{\epsilon \rightarrow 0^{-}} \frac{\mathbb{E} e^{-q \tau_{\epsilon}}\left(\mathbb{P}_{\epsilon}\left(X_{e_{q}}^{2} \in \mathrm{~d} y\right)-\mathbb{E}_{\epsilon} e^{-q \tau_{0}} \mathbb{P}\left(X_{e_{q}}^{2} \in \mathrm{~d} y\right)\right)}{1-\mathbb{E} e^{-q \tau_{\epsilon}} \mathbb{E}_{\epsilon} e^{-q \tau_{0}}} \\
& =\lim _{\epsilon \rightarrow 0^{-}} \frac{\mathbb{P}_{\epsilon}\left(X_{e_{q}}^{2} \in \mathrm{~d} y\right)-e^{\rho_{2}^{-} \epsilon} \mathbb{P}\left(X_{e_{q}}^{2} \in \mathrm{~d} y\right)}{\left(c_{1}(q)-1\right) e^{\rho_{2}^{-} \epsilon}+\left(1-c_{1}(q)\right) e^{\rho_{1}^{-} \epsilon}} \quad \text { l'Hôpital's rule } \\
& =\lim _{\epsilon \rightarrow 0^{-}} \frac{\frac{q}{d \epsilon} \mathbb{P}_{\epsilon}\left(X_{e_{q}}^{2} \in \mathrm{~d} y\right)-\rho_{2}^{-} e^{\rho_{2}^{-} \epsilon} \mathbb{P}\left(X_{e_{q}}^{2} \in \mathrm{~d} y\right)}{\left(c_{1}(q)-1\right) \rho_{2}^{-} e^{\rho_{2}^{-} \epsilon}+\left(1-c_{1}(q)\right) \rho_{1}^{-} e^{\rho_{1}^{-} \epsilon}}} \\
& =\lim _{\epsilon \rightarrow 0^{-}} \frac{\frac{q}{d^{-}}\left(-\mu_{-}-\delta^{-}\right) e^{\left(\mu_{-}+\delta^{-}\right)(y-\epsilon)}-\rho_{2}^{-} e^{\rho_{2}^{-} \epsilon} \frac{q}{d^{2}} e^{\left(\mu_{-}+\delta^{-}\right) y}}{\left(c_{1}(q)-1\right) \rho_{2}^{-} e^{\rho_{2}^{-} \epsilon}+\left(1-c_{1}(q)\right) \rho_{1}^{-} e^{\rho_{1}^{-} \epsilon}}} \mathrm{~d} y \\
& =\frac{-\frac{q}{d^{-}}\left(\rho_{2}^{-}-\rho_{1}^{-}\right) e^{\left(\mu_{-}+\delta^{-}\right) y}}{-\left(1-c_{1}(q)\right)\left(\rho_{2}^{-}-\rho_{1}^{-}\right)} \mathrm{d} y \\
& =\frac{q}{\delta^{-}\left(1-c_{1}(q)\right)} e^{\left(\mu_{-}+\delta^{-}\right) y} \mathrm{~d} y
\end{aligned}
$$

where $\mathbb{P}\left(X_{e_{q}}^{2} \in \mathrm{~d} y\right)=\frac{q}{\delta^{-}} e^{\left(\mu_{-}+\delta^{-}\right) y} \mathrm{~d} y$. Substituting $\delta^{-}$and $c_{1}(q)$,

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \int_{0}^{\infty} q e^{-q t} \mathbb{P}\left(X_{t} \in \mathrm{~d} y\right) \mathrm{d} t= \\
& \frac{2(1-\beta) q}{(1+\beta) \mu_{+}-(1-\beta) \mu_{-}+(1+\beta) \sqrt{\mu_{+}^{2}+2 q}+(1-\beta) \sqrt{\mu_{-}^{2}+2 q}} e^{\left(\mu_{-}+\sqrt{\mu_{-}^{2}+2 q}\right) y} \mathrm{~d} y
\end{aligned}
$$

We can also identify the potential measure for SBM with arbitrary initial value.
Proposition 1. The potential measure of the refracted skew Brownian motion $X_{t}$ with skew level $a=0$ and starting point $x$ is given by:
for $y>0$

$$
\mathbb{P}_{x}\left(X_{e_{q}} \in \mathrm{~d} y\right)=\left\{\begin{array}{l}
\frac{q e^{\mu_{+}(y-\epsilon)}}{\sqrt{\mu_{+}^{2}+2 q}}\left(e^{-|y-x| \sqrt{\mu_{+}^{2}+2 q}}-e^{-(x+y) \sqrt{\mu_{+}^{2}+2 q}}\right) \mathrm{d} y \\
+\frac{2(1+\beta) q}{(1+\beta) \mu_{+}-(1-\beta) \mu_{-}+(1+\beta) \sqrt{\mu_{+}^{2}+2 q+(1-\beta) \sqrt{\mu_{-}^{2}+2 q}}} e^{\mu_{+}(y-x)-(x+y) \sqrt{\mu_{+}^{2}+2 q}} \mathrm{~d} y, \quad x \geq 0 \\
\frac{2(1+\beta) q}{(1+\beta) \mu_{+}-(1-\beta) \mu_{-}+(1+\beta) \sqrt{\mu_{+}^{2}+2 q+(1-\beta) \sqrt{\mu_{-}^{2}+2 q}}} e^{\left(-\mu_{-}+\sqrt{\mu_{-}^{2}+2 q}\right) y} e^{\left(\mu_{+}-\sqrt{\mu_{+}^{2}+2 q}\right) y} \mathrm{~d} y, \quad x \leq 0
\end{array}\right.
$$

and for $y<0$

$$
\mathbb{P}_{x}\left(X_{e_{q}} \in \mathrm{~d} y\right)=\left\{\begin{array}{l}
\frac{2(1-\beta) q}{(1+\beta) \mu_{+}-(1-\beta) \mu_{-}+(1+\beta) \sqrt{\mu_{+}^{2}+2 q+(1-\beta) \sqrt{\mu_{-}^{2}+2 q}} e^{\left(-\mu_{+}-\sqrt{\mu_{+}^{2}+2 q}\right) x} e^{\left(\mu_{-}+\sqrt{\mu_{-}^{2}+2 q}\right) y} \mathrm{~d} y, \quad x \geq 0 \\
\frac{\mu_{-\left(1+\beta\right)}^{\mu_{-}(1-\beta)}}{\sqrt{\mu_{-}^{2}+2 q}}\left(e^{-|y-x| \sqrt{\mu_{-}^{2}+2 q}}-e^{(x+y) \sqrt{\mu_{-}^{2}+2 q}}\right) \mathrm{d} y \\
+\frac{2(1-\beta) q}{(1+\beta) \mu_{+}-(1-\beta) \mu_{-}+(1+\beta) \sqrt{\mu_{+}^{2}+2 q+(1-\beta) \sqrt{\mu_{-}^{2}+2 q}}} e^{\mu_{-}(y-x)+(x+y) \sqrt{\mu_{-}^{2}+2 q}} \mathrm{~d} y . \quad x \leq 0
\end{array}\right.
$$

Proof. CASE 1: $x \geq 0$ and $y>0$,

$$
\begin{aligned}
\mathbb{P}_{x}\left(X_{e_{q}} \in \mathrm{~d} y\right) & =\mathbb{P}_{x}\left(X_{e_{q}} \in \mathrm{~d} y, e_{q}<\tau_{0}\right)+\mathbb{P}_{x}\left(X_{e_{q}} \in \mathrm{~d} y, e_{q}>\tau_{0}\right) \\
& =\mathbb{P}_{x}\left(X_{e_{q}}^{1} \in \mathrm{~d} y, e_{q}<\tau_{0}^{1}\right)+\mathbb{P}_{x}\left(e_{q}>\tau_{0}\right) \mathbb{P}\left(X_{e_{q}} \in \mathrm{~d} y\right) \\
& =\mathbb{P}_{x}\left(X_{e_{q}}^{1} \in \mathrm{~d} y\right)-\mathbb{P}_{x}\left(X_{e_{q}}^{1} \in \mathrm{~d} y, e_{q}>\tau_{0}^{1}\right)+\mathbb{P}_{x}\left(e_{q}>\tau_{0}\right) \mathbb{P}\left(X_{e_{q}} \in \mathrm{~d} y\right) \\
& =\mathbb{P}_{x}\left(X_{e_{q}}^{1} \in \mathrm{~d} y\right)-\mathbb{E}_{x} e^{-q \tau_{0}^{1}} \mathbb{P}\left(X_{e_{q}}^{1} \in \mathrm{~d} y\right)+\mathbb{E}_{x} e^{-q \tau_{0}} \mathbb{P}\left(X_{e_{q}} \in \mathrm{~d} y\right) \\
& =\frac{q e^{\mu_{+}(y-x)}}{\sqrt{\mu_{+}^{2}+2 q}}\left(e^{-|y-x| \sqrt{\mu_{+}^{2}+2 q}}-e^{-(x+y) \sqrt{\mu_{+}^{2}+2 q}}\right) \mathrm{d} y \\
& +\frac{2(1+\beta) q}{(1+\beta) \mu_{+}-(1-\beta) \mu_{-}+(1+\beta) \sqrt{\mu_{+}^{2}+2 q}+(1-\beta) \sqrt{\mu_{-}^{2}+2 q}} e^{\mu_{+}(y-x)-(x+y) \sqrt{\mu_{+}^{2}+2 q}} \mathrm{~d} y
\end{aligned}
$$

CASE 2: $x \leq 0$ and $y>0$,

$$
\begin{aligned}
\mathbb{P}_{x}\left(X_{e_{q}} \in \mathrm{~d} y\right)= & \mathbb{P}_{x}\left(X_{e_{q}} \in \mathrm{~d} y, e_{q}>\tau_{0}\right) \\
= & \mathbb{P}_{x}\left(e_{q}>\tau_{0}\right) \mathbb{P}\left(X_{e_{q}} \in \mathrm{~d} y\right) \\
= & \mathbb{E}_{x} e^{-q \tau_{0}} \mathbb{P}\left(X_{e_{q}} \in \mathrm{~d} y\right) \\
= & \frac{2(1+\beta) q}{(1+\beta) \mu_{+}-(1-\beta) \mu_{-}+(1+\beta) \sqrt{\mu_{+}^{2}+2 q}+(1-\beta) \sqrt{\mu_{-}^{2}+2 q}} \\
& \times e^{\left(-\mu_{-}+\sqrt{\mu_{-}^{2}+2 q}\right) x} e^{\left(\mu_{+}-\sqrt{\mu_{+}^{2}+2 q}\right) y} \mathrm{~d} y
\end{aligned}
$$

CASE 3: $x \geq 0$ and $y<0$,

$$
\begin{aligned}
\mathbb{P}_{x}\left(X_{e_{q}} \in \mathrm{~d} y\right)= & \mathbb{P}_{x}\left(X_{e_{q}} \in \mathrm{~d} y, e_{q}>\tau_{0}\right) \\
= & \mathbb{P}_{x}\left(e_{q}>\tau_{0}\right) \mathbb{P}\left(X_{e_{q}} \in \mathrm{~d} y\right) \\
= & \mathbb{E}_{x} e^{-q \tau_{0}} \mathbb{P}\left(X_{e_{q}} \in \mathrm{~d} y\right) \\
= & \frac{2(1-\beta) q}{(1+\beta) \mu_{+}-(1-\beta) \mu_{-}+(1+\beta) \sqrt{\mu_{+}^{2}+2 q}+(1-\beta) \sqrt{\mu_{-}^{2}+2 q}} \\
& \times e^{\left(-\mu_{+}-\sqrt{\mu_{+}^{2}+2 q}\right) x} e^{\left(\mu_{-}+\sqrt{\mu_{-}^{2}+2 q}\right) y} \mathrm{~d} y
\end{aligned}
$$

CASE 4: $x \leq 0$ and $y>0$

$$
\begin{aligned}
\mathbb{P}_{x}\left(X_{e_{q}} \in \mathrm{~d} y\right) & =\mathbb{P}_{x}\left(X_{e_{q}} \in \mathrm{~d} y, e_{q}<\tau_{0}\right)+\mathbb{P}_{x}\left(X_{e_{q}} \in \mathrm{~d} y, e_{q}>\tau_{0}\right) \\
& =\mathbb{P}_{x}\left(X_{e_{q}}^{2} \in \mathrm{~d} y, e_{q}<\tau_{0}^{2}\right)+\mathbb{P}_{x}\left(e_{q}>\tau_{0}\right) \mathbb{P}\left(X_{e_{q}} \in \mathrm{~d} y\right) \\
& =\mathbb{P}_{x}\left(X_{e_{q}}^{2} \in \mathrm{~d} y\right)-\mathbb{P}_{x}\left(X_{e_{q}}^{2} \in \mathrm{~d} y, e_{q}>\tau_{0}^{2}\right)+\mathbb{P}_{x}\left(e_{q}>\tau_{0}\right) \mathbb{P}\left(X_{e_{q}} \in \mathrm{~d} y\right) \\
& =\mathbb{P}_{x}\left(X_{e_{q}}^{2} \in \mathrm{~d} y\right)-\mathbb{E}_{x} e^{-q \tau_{0}^{2}} \mathbb{P}\left(X_{e_{q}}^{2} \in \mathrm{~d} y\right)+\mathbb{E}_{x} e^{-q \tau_{0}} \mathbb{P}\left(X_{e_{q}} \in \mathrm{~d} y\right) \\
& =\frac{q e^{\mu_{-}(y-x)}}{\sqrt{\mu_{-}^{2}+2 q}}\left(e^{-|y-x| \sqrt{\mu_{-}^{2}+2 q}}-e^{(x+y) \sqrt{\mu_{-}^{2}+2 q}}\right) \mathrm{d} y \\
& +\frac{2(1-\beta) q}{(1+\beta) \mu_{+}-(1-\beta) \mu_{-}+(1+\beta) \sqrt{\mu_{+}^{2}+2 q}+(1-\beta) \sqrt{\mu_{-}^{2}+2 q}} e^{\mu_{-}(y-x)+(x+y) \sqrt{\mu_{-}^{2}+2 q}} \mathrm{~d} y
\end{aligned}
$$

Remark 2. Proposition 1 is obtained in (1.6) of [8]. However, note that there is a typo in the first term of (1.6) when $z>0$ and $x \geq 0$ : all terms in the exponential functions should involve $\mu$.

We further consider the potential measure with barriers imposed. If $b_{-}<x<b_{+}$, then, starting from $x$ with skew level is zero, the probability that $X_{e_{q}}$ remains between $b_{-}$and $b_{+}$is:
Proposition 2. Given $b_{-}<0<b_{+}, X_{0}=x, a=0$, the potential measure of the refracted skew Brownian motion with barriers at $b_{-}$and $b_{+}$is given by

$$
\mathbb{P}_{x}\left(X_{e_{q}} \in \mathrm{~d} y, e_{q}<\tau_{b_{-}} \wedge \tau_{b_{+}}\right)=\mathbb{P}_{x}\left(X_{e_{q}} \in \mathrm{~d} y\right)-\frac{w\left(x, b_{+}\right)}{w\left(b_{-}, b_{+}\right)} \mathbb{P}_{b_{-}}\left(X_{e_{q}} \in \mathrm{~d} y\right)-\frac{w\left(x, b_{-}\right)}{w\left(b_{+}, b_{-}\right)} \mathbb{P}_{b_{+}}\left(X_{e_{q}} \in \mathrm{~d} y\right)
$$

and remaining below or above level $b_{-}$is:

$$
\mathbb{P}_{x}\left(X_{e_{q}} \in \mathrm{~d} y, e_{q}<\tau_{b_{-}}\right)=\mathbb{P}_{x}\left(X_{e_{q}} \in \mathrm{~d} y\right)-\mathbb{E}_{x} e^{-q \tau_{b_{-}}} \mathbb{P}_{b_{-}}\left(X_{e_{q}} \in \mathrm{~d} y\right)
$$

Proof.

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \mathbb{P}_{x}\left(X_{e_{q}} \in \mathrm{~d} y, e_{q}<\tau_{b_{-}} \wedge \tau_{b_{+}}\right) \\
& =\mathbb{P}_{x}\left(X_{e_{q}} \in \mathrm{~d} y\right)-\mathbb{P}_{x}\left(\tau_{b_{-}}<e_{q} \wedge \tau_{b_{+}}, X_{e_{q}} \in \mathrm{~d} y\right)-\mathbb{P}_{x}\left(\tau_{b_{+}}<e_{q} \wedge \tau_{b_{-}}, X_{e_{q}} \in \mathrm{~d} y\right) \\
& =\mathbb{P}_{x}\left(X_{e_{q}} \in \mathrm{~d} y\right)-\mathbb{P}_{x}\left(\tau_{b_{-}}<e_{q} \wedge \tau_{b_{+}}\right) \mathbb{P}_{b_{-}}\left(X_{e_{q}} \in \mathrm{~d} y\right)-\mathbb{P}_{x}\left(\tau_{b_{+}}<e_{q} \wedge \tau_{b_{-}}\right) \mathbb{P}_{b_{+}}\left(X_{e_{q}} \in \mathrm{~d} y\right) \\
& =\mathbb{P}_{x}\left(X_{e_{q}} \in \mathrm{~d} y\right)-\mathbb{E}_{x}\left(e^{-q \tau_{b_{-}}}, \tau_{b_{-}}<\tau_{b_{+}}\right) \mathbb{P}_{b_{-}}\left(X_{e_{q}} \in \mathrm{~d} y\right)-\mathbb{E}_{x}\left(e^{-q \tau_{b_{+}}}, \tau_{b_{+}}<\tau_{b_{-}}\right) \mathbb{P}_{b_{+}}\left(X_{e_{q}} \in \mathrm{~d} y\right) \\
& =\mathbb{P}_{x}\left(X_{e_{q}} \in \mathrm{~d} y\right)-\frac{w\left(x, b_{+}\right)}{w\left(b_{-}, b_{+}\right)} \mathbb{P}_{b_{-}}\left(X_{e_{q}} \in \mathrm{~d} y\right)-\frac{w\left(x, b_{-}\right)}{w\left(b_{+}, b_{-}\right)} \mathbb{P}_{b_{+}}\left(X_{e_{q}} \in \mathrm{~d} y\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

For the second part:

$$
\begin{aligned}
\mathbb{P}_{x}\left(X_{e_{q}} \in \mathrm{~d} y, e_{q}<\tau_{b_{-}}\right) & =\mathbb{P}_{x}\left(X_{e_{q}} \in \mathrm{~d} y\right)-\mathbb{P}_{x}\left(X_{e_{q}} \in \mathrm{~d} y, e_{q}>\tau_{b_{-}}\right) \\
& =\mathbb{P}_{x}\left(X_{e_{q}} \in \mathrm{~d} y\right)-\mathbb{P}_{x}\left(e_{q}>\tau_{b_{-}}\right) \mathbb{P}_{b_{-}}\left(X_{e_{q}} \in \mathrm{~d} y\right) \\
& =\mathbb{P}_{x}\left(X_{e_{q}} \in \mathrm{~d} y\right)-\mathbb{E}_{x} e^{-q \tau_{b_{-}}} \mathbb{P}_{b_{-}}\left(X_{e_{q}} \in \mathrm{~d} y\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

# IV Transition density of RSBM 

In this section, we obtain the transition probability of an RSBM by inverting the Laplace transform.
We first define an auxiliary function

$$
h(t ; x, \mu):=\frac{|x|}{\sqrt{2 \pi t^{3}}} e^{\frac{-(x+\mu t)^{2}}{2 t}}, \quad x, \mu \in \mathbb{R}, t>0
$$

where its Laplace transform for $x \neq 0$ is given by:

$$
\int_{0}^{\infty} e^{-q t} h(t ; x, \mu) \mathrm{d} t=\exp \left[-(\mu+\operatorname{sgn}(x) \sqrt{2 q+\mu^{2}}) x\right]
$$

and zero for $x=0$. Additionally, we have the following properties for $h$ :

$$
h(t ; x, \mu)=h(t ;-x,-\mu), \quad h(t ; x,-\mu)=h(t ;-x, \mu)=e^{2 \mu x} h(t ; x, \mu)
$$

and

$$
h\left(t ; x_{1}+x_{2}, \mu\right)=\int_{0}^{t} h\left(t-\tau ; x_{1}, \mu\right) h\left(\tau ; x_{2}, \mu\right) \mathrm{d} \tau
$$

see [25].

Theorem 4. The density probability of the refracted skew Brownian motion, with skew level $a=0$ and starting point $x=0$ is given by:

$$
p(t ; y)= \begin{cases}2(1+\beta) e^{2 \mu_{+} y} \int_{0}^{\infty} \int_{0}^{t} h(t-\tau ;(1+\beta) b+y, \mu_{+}) h(\tau ;(1-\beta) b,-\mu_{-}) \mathrm{d} \tau \mathrm{~d} b, & y>0 \\ 2(1-\beta) e^{2 \mu_{-} y} \int_{0}^{\infty} \int_{0}^{t} h(t-\tau ;(1+\beta) b, \mu_{+}) h(\tau ;(1-\beta) b-y,-\mu_{-}) \mathrm{d} \tau \mathrm{~d} b, & y<0\end{cases}
$$

Proof. For $y>0$, taking the Laplace transform for $p(t ; y)$ in (19) we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \int_{0}^{\infty} e^{-q t} \mathbb{P}\left(X_{t} \in \mathrm{~d} y\right) \mathrm{d} t=\int_{0}^{\infty} e^{-q t} p(t ; y) \mathrm{d} t \mathrm{~d} y \\
= & 2(1+\beta) e^{2 \mu_{+} y} \int_{0}^{\infty} \int_{0}^{\infty} e^{-q t} \int_{0}^{t} h(t-\tau ;(1+\beta) b+y, \mu_{+}) h(\tau ;(1-\beta) b,-\mu_{-}) \mathrm{d} \tau \mathrm{~d} t \mathrm{~d} b d y \\
= & 2(1+\beta) e^{2 \mu_{+} y} \int_{0}^{\infty}\left[\int_{0}^{\infty} e^{-q t} h(t ;(1+\beta) b+y, \mu_{+}) \mathrm{d} t\right]\left[\int_{0}^{\infty} e^{-q t} h(t ;(1-\beta) b,-\mu_{-}) \mathrm{d} t\right] \mathrm{d} b \mathrm{~d} y \\
= & 2(1+\beta) e^{2 \mu_{+} y} \int_{0}^{\infty}\left[\exp \left(-\left(\mu_{+}+\sqrt{2 q+\mu_{+}^{2}}\right)((1+\beta) b+y)\right)\right]\left[\exp \left(-\left(-\mu_{-}+\sqrt{2 q+\mu_{-}^{2}}\right)((1-\beta) b)\right)\right] \mathrm{d} b \mathrm{~d} y \\
= & 2(1+\beta) e^{2 \mu_{+} y} \int_{0}^{\infty} e^{\rho_{1}^{+}((1+\beta) b+y)} e^{-\rho_{2}^{-}(1-\beta) b} \mathrm{~d} b \mathrm{~d} y \\
= & 2(1+\beta) e^{2 \mu_{+} y} e^{\rho_{1}^{+} y} \int_{0}^{\infty} e^{\rho_{1}^{+} (1+\beta) b} e^{-\rho_{2}^{-}(1-\beta) b} \mathrm{~d} b \mathrm{~d} y \\
= & 2(1+\beta) e^{-\rho_{2}^{+} y} \int_{0}^{\infty} e^{-(-(1+\beta) \rho_{1}^{+}+(1-\beta) \rho_{2}^{-}) b} \mathrm{~d} b \mathrm{~d} y \\
= & \frac{2(1+\beta)}{-(1+\beta) \rho_{1}^{+}+(1-\beta) \rho_{2}^{-}} e^{-\rho_{2}^{+} y} \mathrm{~d} y \\
= & \frac{2(1+\beta)}{(1+\beta)\left[\mu_{+}+\sqrt{2 q+\mu_{+}^{2}}\right]+(1-\beta)\left[-\mu_{-}+\sqrt{2 q+\mu_{-}^{2}}\right]} e^{\left(\mu_{+}-\sqrt{2 q+\mu_{+}^{2}}\right) y} \mathrm{~d} y
\end{aligned}
$$

which recovers (8).
Similarly, for $y<0$,

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \int_{0}^{\infty} e^{-q t} \mathbb{P}\left(X_{t} \in \mathrm{~d} y\right) \mathrm{d} t=\int_{0}^{\infty} e^{-q t} p(t ; y) \mathrm{d} t \mathrm{~d} y \\
= & 2(1-\beta) e^{2 \mu_{-} y} \int_{0}^{\infty} \int_{0}^{\infty} e^{-q t} \int_{0}^{t} h(t-\tau ;(1+\beta) b, \mu_{+}) h(\tau ;(1-\beta) b-y,-\mu_{-}) \mathrm{d} \tau \mathrm{~d} t \mathrm{~d} b \mathrm{~d} y \\
= & 2(1-\beta) e^{2 \mu_{-} y} \int_{0}^{\infty}\left[\int_{0}^{\infty} e^{-q t} h(t ;(1+\beta) b, \mu_{+}) \mathrm{d} t\right]\left[\int_{0}^{\infty} e^{-q t} h(t ;(1-\beta) b-y,-\mu_{-}) \mathrm{d} t\right] \mathrm{d} b \mathrm{~d} y \\
= & 2(1-\beta) e^{2 \mu_{-} y} \int_{0}^{\infty}\left[\exp \left(-\left(\mu_{+}+\sqrt{2 q+\mu_{+}^{2}}\right)(1+\beta) b\right)\right]\left[\exp \left(-\left(-\mu_{-}+\sqrt{2 q+\mu_{-}^{2}}\right)((1-\beta) b-y)\right)\right] \mathrm{d} b \mathrm{~d} y \\
= & 2(1-\beta) e^{2 \mu_{-} y} \int_{0}^{\infty} e^{\rho_{1}^{+}(1+\beta) b} e^{-\rho_{2}^{-}((1-\beta)-y) b} \mathrm{~d} b \mathrm{~d} y \\
= & 2(1-\beta) e^{2 \mu_{-} y} e^{\rho_{2}^{-} y} \int_{0}^{\infty} e^{\rho_{1}^{+}(1+\beta) b} e^{-\rho_{2}^{-}(1-\beta) b} \mathrm{~d} b \mathrm{~d} y \\
= & 2(1-\beta) e^{-\rho_{1}^{-} y} \int_{0}^{\infty} e^{-(-(1+\beta) \rho_{1}^{+}+(1-\beta) \rho_{2}^{-}) b} \mathrm{~d} b \mathrm{~d} y \\
= & \frac{2(1-\beta)}{-(1+\beta) \rho_{1}^{+}+(1-\beta) \rho_{2}^{-}} e^{-\rho_{1}^{-} y} \mathrm{~d} y \\
= & \frac{2(1-\beta)}{(1+\beta)\left[\mu_{+}+\sqrt{2 q+\mu_{+}^{2}}\right]+(1-\beta)\left[-\mu_{-}+\sqrt{2 q+\mu_{-}^{2}}\right]} e^{\left(\mu_{-}+\sqrt{2 q+\mu_{-}^{2}}\right) y} \mathrm{~d} y
\end{aligned}
$$

which recovers (8).

Remark 3. Our result aligns with the marginal density of $x$ in the joint density provided in equation (2.4) in [15]. But it does not agree with equation (2.3) presented in [15], possibly due to a typo in (2.3) for the case $x>0$. Although the same authors of [16] obtained the density function for the refracted skew Brownian motion containing alternating drifts using equation (2.3), their two results appear to be inconsistent, particularly in more general settings, see Appendix (C), for more details.

The following corollaries concern special cases of Theorem 4, which appear in the previous work on SBM.
Corollary 4.1. The transition probability of a skew Brownian motion with one constant drift, $\mu_{-}=\mu_{+}=\mu$, with skew level $a=0$ and starting point $x=0$ is given by:

$$
p(t ; y)= \begin{cases}\frac{(1+\beta)}{\sqrt{2 \pi t}} e^{\frac{-(y-\mu t)^{2}}{2 t}}\left[1-\frac{\beta \mu}{2} \sqrt{2 \pi t} e^{\frac{(y+\beta \mu t)^{2}}{2 t}} \operatorname{erfc}\left(\frac{y+\beta \mu t}{\sqrt{2 t}}\right)\right] \mathrm{d} y, & y>0 \\ \frac{(1-\beta)}{\sqrt{2 \pi t}} e^{\frac{-(y-\mu t)^{2}}{2 t}}\left[1-\frac{\beta \mu}{2} \sqrt{2 \pi t} e^{\frac{(-y+\beta \mu t)^{2}}{2 t}} \operatorname{erfc}\left(\frac{-y+\beta \mu t}{\sqrt{2 t}}\right)\right] \mathrm{d} y, & y<0\end{cases}
$$

where $\operatorname{erfc}(z)$ is a complementary error function given by

$$
\operatorname{erfc}(z)=\frac{2}{\sqrt{\pi}} \int_{z}^{\infty} e^{-t^{2}} d t
$$

The proof is deferred to the appendix A. Note that it recovers the previous result in [2]. For $\mu=0$, it corresponds to a result in [32].
Corollary 4.2. The transition probability of a skew Brownian motion with two alternating drifts, $-\mu_{-}=\mu_{+}=\mu$, with skew level $a=0$ and starting point $x=0$ is given by:

$$
p(t ; y)= \begin{cases}\frac{(1+\beta)}{\sqrt{2 \pi t}} e^{\frac{-(y-\mu t)^{2}}{2 t}}\left[1-\frac{\mu}{2} \sqrt{2 \pi t} e^{\frac{(y+\mu t)^{2}}{2 t}} \operatorname{erfc}\left(\frac{y+\mu t}{\sqrt{2 t}}\right)\right] \mathrm{d} y, & y>0 \\ \frac{(1-\beta)}{\sqrt{2 \pi t}} e^{\frac{-(y+\mu t)^{2}}{2 t}}\left[1-\frac{\mu}{2} \sqrt{2 \pi t} e^{\frac{(-y+\mu t)^{2}}{2 t}} \operatorname{erfc}\left(\frac{-y+\mu t}{\sqrt{2 t}}\right)\right] \mathrm{d} y, & y<0\end{cases}
$$

Which agrees with [16]. The proof is similar to the previous corollary, so we omit it.
Corollary 4.3. Define $f(t ; y)$ as the following:

$$
f(t ; y):= \begin{cases}\int_{0}^{\infty} \int_{0}^{t} h(t-\tau ;(1+\beta) b+y, \mu_{+}) h(\tau ;(1-\beta) b,-\mu_{-}) \mathrm{d} \tau \mathrm{~d} b, & y>0 \\ \int_{0}^{\infty} \int_{0}^{t} h(t-\tau ;(1+\beta) b, \mu_{+}) h(\tau ;(1-\beta) b-y,-\mu_{-}) \mathrm{d} \tau \mathrm{~d} b, & y<0\end{cases}
$$

the Laplace transform of $f(t ; y)$ is given by:

$$
\hat{f}(q ; y)= \begin{cases}\frac{1}{(1+\beta)\left[\mu_{+}+\sqrt{2 q+\mu_{+}^{2}}\right]+(1-\beta)\left[-\mu_{-}+\sqrt{2 q+\mu_{-}^{2}}\right]} e^{\left(-\mu_{+}-\sqrt{2 q+\mu_{+}^{2}}\right) y}, & y>0 \\ \frac{1}{(1+\beta)\left[\mu_{+}+\sqrt{2 q+\mu_{+}^{2}}\right]+(1-\beta)\left[-\mu_{-}+\sqrt{2 q+\mu_{-}^{2}}\right]} e^{\left(-\mu_{-}+\sqrt{2 q+\mu_{-}^{2}}\right) y}, & y<0\end{cases}
$$

For simplicity we set $f^{-}(t ; y)$ and $\hat{f}^{-}(q ; y)$ to be the functions defined in Corollary 4.3 for $y<0$, and set $f^{+}(t ; y)$, $\hat{f}^{+}(q ; y)$, when $y>0$.
Proposition 3. The cumulative distribution function (CDF) of the refracted skew Brownian motion with skew level $a=0$ and initial $x=0$ is given by: for $z<0$ :

$$
\begin{aligned}
\mathrm{P}(Z \leq z) & =2(1-\beta) \int_{0}^{\infty} e^{2 \mu_{-}(1-\beta) b}\left[\int_{0}^{t} \frac{1}{\sqrt{2 \pi \tau}} h(t-\tau ;(1+\beta) b, \mu_{+}) \exp \left(\frac{-((1-\beta) b-z+\mu_{-} \tau)^{2}}{2 \tau}\right) \mathrm{d} \tau\right. \\
& \left.-\frac{\mu_{-}}{2} \int_{0}^{t} h(t-\tau ;(1+\beta) b, \mu_{+}) \operatorname{erfc}\left(\frac{(1-\beta) b-z+\mu_{-} \tau}{\sqrt{2 \tau}}\right) \mathrm{d} \tau\right] \mathrm{d} b
\end{aligned}
$$

and for $z>0$ :

$$
\begin{aligned}
\mathrm{P}(Z \leq z) & =1-2(1+\beta) \int_{0}^{\infty} e^{-2 \mu_{+}(1+\beta) b}\left[\int_{0}^{t} \frac{1}{\sqrt{2 \pi \tau}} h(t-\tau ;(1-\beta) b,-\mu_{-}) \exp \left(\frac{-((1+\beta) b+z-\mu_{+} \tau)^{2}}{2 \tau}\right) \mathrm{d} \tau\right. \\
& \left.+\frac{\mu_{+}}{2} \int_{0}^{t} h(t-\tau ;(1-\beta) b,-\mu_{-}) \operatorname{erfc}\left(\frac{(1+\beta) b+z-\mu_{+} \tau}{\sqrt{2 \tau}}\right) \mathrm{d} \tau\right] \mathrm{d} b
\end{aligned}
$$

Based on Proposition 1 and Corollary 4.3 we can derive the transition probability of the refracted skew Brownian motion when the starting point is any real value $x$.
Proposition 4. The transition probability of the refracted skew Brownian motion, with skew level $a=0$ and starting point $x$ is given by:
for $y>0$

$$
p(t ; x, y)=\left\{\begin{array}{l}
{\left[\phi\left(y-x ; \mu_{+}\right)-e^{-2 \mu_{+} x} \phi\left(x+y ; \mu_{+}\right)\right]} \\
+2(1+\beta) e^{2 \mu_{+} y} \int_{0}^{\infty} \int_{0}^{t} h\left(t-\tau ;(1+\beta) b+x+y, \mu_{+}\right) h\left(\tau ;(1-\beta) b,-\mu_{-}\right) \mathrm{d} \tau \mathrm{~d} b, \quad x \geq 0 \\
2(1+\beta) e^{2 \mu_{+} y} \int_{0}^{\infty} \int_{0}^{t} h\left(\tau ;(1+\beta) b+y, \mu_{+}\right) h\left(t-\tau ;(1-\beta) b-x,-\mu_{-}\right) \mathrm{d} \tau \mathrm{~d} b, \quad x<0
\end{array}\right.
$$

and for $y<0$

$$
p(t ; x, y)=\left\{\begin{array}{l}
2(1-\beta) e^{2 \mu_{-} y} \int_{0}^{\infty} \int_{0}^{t} h\left(t-\tau ;(1+\beta) b+x, \mu_{+}\right) h\left(\tau ;(1-\beta) b-y,-\mu_{-}\right) \mathrm{d} \tau \mathrm{~d} b, \quad x>0 \\
{\left[\phi\left(y-x ; \mu_{-}\right)-e^{2 \mu_{-} y} \phi\left(-x-y ; \mu_{-}\right)\right]} \\
+2(1-\beta) e^{2 \mu_{-} y} \int_{0}^{\infty} \int_{0}^{t} h\left(\tau ;(1+\beta) b, \mu_{+}\right) h\left(t-\tau ;(1-\beta) b-y-x,-\mu_{-}\right) \mathrm{d} \tau \mathrm{~d} b, \quad x \leq 0
\end{array}\right.
$$

where $\phi(z ; \mu)$ is the density function of a Brownian motion with drift $\mu$ defined by:

$$
\phi(z ; \mu)=\frac{1}{\sqrt{2 \pi t}} \exp \frac{-(z-\mu t)^{2}}{2 t} \mathrm{~d} z
$$

The proof is provided in appendix B.
Corollary 4.4. The transition probability of the refracted Brownian motion with starting point $x$ is given by:
For $y>0$,

$$
p(t ; x, y)=\left\{\begin{array}{l}
{\left[\phi\left(y-x ; \mu_{+}\right)-e^{-2 \mu_{+} x} \phi\left(x+y ; \mu_{+}\right)\right]} \\
+2 e^{2 \mu_{+} y} \int_{0}^{\infty} \int_{0}^{t} h\left(t-\tau ; b+x+y, \mu_{+}\right) h\left(\tau ; b,-\mu_{-}\right) \mathrm{d} \tau \mathrm{~d} b, \quad x \geq 0 \\
2 e^{2 \mu_{+} y} \int_{0}^{\infty} \int_{0}^{t} h\left(\tau ; b+y, \mu_{+}\right) h\left(t-\tau ; b-x,-\mu_{-}\right) \mathrm{d} \tau \mathrm{~d} b, \quad x<0
\end{array}\right.
$$

and for $y<0$,

$$
p(t ; x, y)=\left\{\begin{array}{l}
2 e^{2 \mu_{-} y} \int_{0}^{\infty} \int_{0}^{t} h\left(t-\tau ; b+x, \mu_{+}\right) h\left(\tau ; b-y,-\mu_{-}\right) \mathrm{d} \tau \mathrm{~d} b, \quad x>0 \\
{\left[\phi\left(y-x ; \mu_{-}\right)-e^{2 \mu_{-} y} \phi\left(-x-y ; \mu_{-}\right)\right]} \\
+2 e^{2 \mu_{-} y} \int_{0}^{\infty} \int_{0}^{t} h\left(\tau ; b, \mu_{+}\right) h\left(t-\tau ; b-y-x,-\mu_{-}\right) \mathrm{d} \tau \mathrm{~d} b, \quad x \leq 0
\end{array}\right.
$$

This recovers the result in [24].
Proposition 5. For the refracted skew Brownian motion with $a=0$, the size of discontinuity for $p(t ; 0, y)$ at $y=0$ is given by

$$
p\left(t ; 0,0^{+}\right)-p\left(t ; 0,0^{-}\right)=4 \beta \int_{0}^{\infty} \int_{0}^{t} h\left(t-\tau ;(1+\beta) b, \mu_{+}\right) h\left(\tau ;(1-\beta) b,-\mu_{-}\right) \mathrm{d} \tau \mathrm{~d} b
$$

If $\beta=0$, i.e. there is no skewness in the process, the jump size is zero and the process is continuous. When $\mu_{-}=\mu_{+}=\mu$, then the jump size is:

$$
\frac{\sqrt{2} \beta}{\sqrt{\pi t}} e^{\frac{-y^{2} t}{2}}\left(1-\frac{\beta \mu}{2} \sqrt{2 \pi} t \operatorname{erfc}\left(\frac{\beta \mu t}{\sqrt{2 t}}\right)\right)
$$

When $-\mu_{-}=\mu_{+}=\mu$, i.e. alternating drifts, the jump size is:

$$
\frac{\sqrt{2} \beta}{\sqrt{\pi t}} e^{\frac{-y^{2} t}{2}}-\beta \mu \operatorname{erfc}\left(\frac{\mu t}{\sqrt{2 t}}\right)
$$

In both cases, when $\mu=0$, the jump size is a linear function of $\beta$ :

$$
\frac{\sqrt{2} \beta}{\sqrt{\pi t}}, \quad t>0
$$

It means that for fixed $t$, when $|\beta|$ is close to 1 , the absolute value of the jump increases.
Based on alternating case we can argue that when $\mu_{-} \rightarrow-\infty$ and $\mu_{+} \rightarrow \infty$, the jump size tends to 0 , and when $\mu_{-} \rightarrow \infty$ and $\mu_{+} \rightarrow-\infty$, the absolute value of jump size tends to $\infty$.

# V Long term behaviors 

In this section, we investigate the behavior of an RSBM as $t$ approaches infinity. When $\mu_{-}>0$ and $\mu_{+}<0$, as $t$ grows larger and larger, the transition probability of the SBM converges to a smooth density that is independent of the starting point $x$.
Proposition 6. Given $\mu_{-}>0$ and $\mu_{+}<0$, for any $x \in \mathbb{R}$ we have

$$
\lim _{t \rightarrow \infty} p(t ; x, y)= \begin{cases}\frac{-2(1+\beta) \mu_{+} \mu_{-}}{(1+\beta) \mu_{-}-(1-\beta) \mu_{+}} e^{2 \mu_{+} y}, & y>0 \\ \frac{-2(1-\beta) \mu_{+} \mu_{-}}{(1+\beta) \mu_{-}-(1-\beta) \mu_{+}} e^{2 \mu_{-} y}, & y<0\end{cases}
$$

Proof. We use the potential measure of SBM to prove this proposition since as $q$ tends to $0, t$ tends to infinity. Suppose $\mu_{-}>0, \mu_{+}<0$, from Proposition (1), when $y>0$ and $x \geq 0$, we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \lim _{t \rightarrow \infty} p(t ; x, y)=\lim _{q \rightarrow 0} \frac{1}{\mathrm{~d} y} \mathbb{P}_{x}\left(X_{e_{q}} \in \mathrm{~d} y\right) \\
& =\lim _{q \rightarrow 0} \frac{q e^{\mu_{+}(y-x)}}{\sqrt{\mu_{+}^{2}+2 q}}\left(e^{-|y-x| \sqrt{\mu_{+}^{2}+2 q}}-e^{-(x+y) \sqrt{\mu_{+}^{2}+2 q}}\right) \\
& +\lim _{q \rightarrow 0} \frac{2(1+\beta) q}{(1+\beta) \mu_{+}-(1-\beta) \mu_{-}+(1+\beta) \sqrt{\mu_{+}^{2}+2 q+(1-\beta) \sqrt{\mu_{-}^{2}+2 q}}} e^{\mu_{+}(y-x)-(x+y) \sqrt{\mu_{+}^{2}+2 q}} \\
& =\lim _{q \rightarrow 0} \frac{2(1+\beta) e^{\mu_{+}(y-x)-(x+y) \sqrt{\mu_{+}^{2}+2 q}}+2(1+\beta) q \frac{\mathrm{~d}}{\mathrm{~d} q}\left(e^{\mu_{+}(y-x)-(x+y) \sqrt{\mu_{+}^{2}+2 q}}\right)}{(1+\beta)\left(\mu_{+}^{2}+2 q\right)^{\frac{-1}{2}}+(1-\beta)\left(\mu_{-}^{2}+2 q\right)^{\frac{-1}{2}}} \quad \text { l'Hôpital's rule } \\
& =\frac{2(1+\beta) e^{\mu_{+}(y-x)-(x+y)\left|\mu_{+}\right|}}{(1+\beta)\left|\mu_{+}\right|^{-1}+(1-\beta)\left|\mu_{-}\right|^{-1}} \quad\left|\mu_{+}\right|=-\mu_{+} \text {and }\left|\mu_{-}\right|=\mu_{-} \\
& =\frac{-2(1+\beta) \mu_{+} \mu_{-}}{(1+\beta) \mu_{-}-(1-\beta) \mu_{+}} e^{2 \mu_{+} y}
\end{aligned}
$$

When $y>0$ and $x \leq 0$, we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \lim _{t \rightarrow \infty} p(t ; x, y)=\lim _{q \rightarrow 0} \frac{1}{\mathrm{~d} y} \mathbb{P}_{x}\left(X_{e_{q}} \in \mathrm{~d} y\right) \\
& =\lim _{q \rightarrow 0} \frac{2(1+\beta) q}{(1+\beta) \mu_{+}-(1-\beta) \mu_{-}+(1+\beta) \sqrt{\mu_{+}^{2}+2 q}+(1-\beta) \sqrt{\mu_{-}^{2}+2 q}} e^{\left(-\mu_{-}+\sqrt{\mu_{-}^{2}+2 q}\right) x} e^{\left(\mu_{+}-\sqrt{\mu_{+}^{2}+2 q}\right) y} \\
& =\lim _{q \rightarrow 0} \frac{2(1+\beta) e^{\left(-\mu_{-}+\sqrt{\mu_{-}^{2}+2 q}\right) x} e^{\left(\mu_{+}-\sqrt{\mu_{+}^{2}+2 q}\right) y}+2(1+\beta) q \frac{\mathrm{~d}}{\mathrm{~d} q}\left(e^{\left(-\mu_{-}+\sqrt{\mu_{-}^{2}+2 q}\right) x} e^{\left(\mu_{+}-\sqrt{\mu_{+}^{2}+2 q}\right) y}\right)}{(1+\beta)\left(\mu_{+}^{2}+2 q\right)^{\frac{-1}{2}}+(1-\beta)\left(\mu_{-}^{2}+2 q\right)^{\frac{-1}{2}}} \quad \text { l'Hôpital's rule } \\
& =\frac{2(1+\beta) e^{\left(-\mu_{-}+\left|\mu_{-}\right|\right) x} e^{\left(\mu_{+}-\left|\mu_{+}\right|\right) y}}{(1+\beta)\left|\mu_{+}\right|^{-1}+(1-\beta)\left|\mu_{-}\right|^{-1}} \quad\left|\mu_{+}\right|=-\mu_{+} \text {and }\left|\mu_{-}\right|=\mu_{-} \\
& =\frac{-2(1+\beta) \mu_{+} \mu_{-}}{(1+\beta) \mu_{-}-(1-\beta) \mu_{+}} e^{2 \mu_{+} y}
\end{aligned}
$$

The desired result follows from a property of the Laplace transform.

When $y<0$ and $x \geq 0$, we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \lim _{t \rightarrow \infty} p(t ; x, y)=\lim _{q \rightarrow 0} \frac{1}{\mathrm{~d} y} \mathbb{P}_{x}\left(X_{e_{q}} \in \mathrm{~d} y\right) \\
& =\lim _{q \rightarrow 0} \frac{2(1-\beta) q}{(1+\beta) \mu_{+}-(1-\beta) \mu_{-}+(1+\beta) \sqrt{\mu_{+}^{2}+2 q}+(1-\beta) \sqrt{\mu_{-}^{2}+2 q}} e^{\left(-\mu_{+}-\sqrt{\mu_{+}^{2}+2 q}\right) x} e^{\left(\mu_{-}+\sqrt{\mu_{-}^{2}+2 q}\right) y} \\
& =\lim _{q \rightarrow 0} \frac{2(1-\beta) e^{\left(-\mu_{+}-\sqrt{\mu_{+}^{2}+2 q}\right) x} e^{\left(\mu_{-}+\sqrt{\mu_{-}^{2}+2 q}\right) y}+2(1-\beta) q \frac{\mathrm{~d}}{\mathrm{~d} q}\left(e^{\left(-\mu_{+}-\sqrt{\mu_{+}^{2}+2 q}\right) x} e^{\left(\mu_{-}+\sqrt{\mu_{-}^{2}+2 q}\right) y}\right)}{(1+\beta)\left(\mu_{+}^{2}+2 q\right)^{\frac{-1}{2}}+(1-\beta)\left(\mu_{-}^{2}+2 q\right)^{\frac{-1}{2}}} \quad \text { l'Hôpital's rule } \\
& =\frac{2(1-\beta) e^{\left(-\mu_{+}-\left|\mu_{+}\right|\right) x} e^{\left(\mu_{-}+\left|\mu_{-}\right|\right) y}}{(1+\beta)\left|\mu_{+}\right|^{-1}+(1-\beta)\left|\mu_{-}\right|^{-1}} \quad\left|\mu_{+}\right|=-\mu_{+} \text {and }\left|\mu_{-}\right|=\mu_{-} \\
& =\frac{-2(1-\beta) \mu_{+} \mu_{-}}{(1+\beta) \mu_{-}-(1-\beta) \mu_{+}} e^{2 \mu_{-} y} .
\end{aligned}
$$

When $y<0$ and $x \leq 0$, we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \lim _{t \rightarrow \infty} p(t ; x, y)=\lim _{q \rightarrow 0} \frac{1}{\mathrm{~d} y} \mathbb{P}_{x}\left(X_{e_{q}} \in \mathrm{~d} y\right) \\
& =\lim _{q \rightarrow 0} \frac{q e^{\mu_{-}(y-x)}}{\sqrt{\mu_{-}^{2}+2 q}}\left(e^{-|y-x| \sqrt{\mu_{-}^{2}+2 q}}-e^{(x+y) \sqrt{\mu_{-}^{2}+2 q}}\right) \\
& +\lim _{q \rightarrow 0} \frac{2(1-\beta) q}{(1+\beta) \mu_{+}-(1-\beta) \mu_{-}+(1+\beta) \sqrt{\mu_{+}^{2}+2 q}+(1-\beta) \sqrt{\mu_{-}^{2}+2 q}} e^{\mu_{-}(y-x)+(x+y) \sqrt{\mu_{-}^{2}+2 q}} \\
& =\lim _{q \rightarrow 0} \frac{2(1-\beta) e^{\mu_{-}(y-x)+(x+y) \sqrt{\mu_{-}^{2}+2 q}}+2(1-\beta) q \frac{\mathrm{~d}}{\mathrm{~d} q}\left(e^{\mu_{-}(y-x)+(x+y) \sqrt{\mu_{-}^{2}+2 q}}\right)}{(1+\beta)\left(\mu_{+}^{2}+2 q\right)^{\frac{-1}{2}}+(1-\beta)\left(\mu_{-}^{2}+2 q\right)^{\frac{-1}{2}}} \quad \text { l'Hôpital's rule } \\
& =\frac{2(1-\beta) e^{\mu_{-}(y-x)+(x+y)\left|\mu_{-}\right|}}{(1+\beta)\left|\mu_{+}\right|^{-1}+(1-\beta)\left|\mu_{-}\right|^{-1}} \quad\left|\mu_{+}\right|=-\mu_{+} \text {and }\left|\mu_{-}\right|=\mu_{-} \\
& =\frac{-2(1-\beta) \mu_{+} \mu_{-}}{(1+\beta) \mu_{-}-(1-\beta) \mu_{+}} e^{2 \mu_{-} y} .
\end{aligned}
$$

For $\mu_{+}>0$ and $\mu_{-}<0$, the probability that an SBM, with sufficiently large $t$, tends towards either positive or negative infinity is determined by the following proposition.
Proposition 7. Given $\mu_{+}>0$ and $\mu_{-}<0$, for any $x \in \mathbb{R}$ we have

$$
\mathbb{P}_{x}\left(\lim _{t \rightarrow \infty} X_{t}=\infty\right)= \begin{cases}\frac{(1+\beta) \mu_{+} e^{-2 \mu_{-} x}}{(1+\beta) \mu_{+}-(1-\beta) \mu_{-}}, & x<0 \\ 1+\frac{(1-\beta) \mu_{-} e^{-2 \mu_{+} x}}{(1+\beta) \mu_{+}-(1-\beta) \mu_{-}}, & x>0\end{cases}
$$

and

$$
\mathbb{P}_{x}\left(\lim _{t \rightarrow \infty} X_{t}=-\infty\right)= \begin{cases}1-\frac{(1+\beta) \mu_{+} e^{-2 \mu_{-} x}}{(1+\beta) \mu_{+}-(1-\beta) \mu_{-}}, & x<0 \\ \frac{-(1-\beta) \mu_{-} e^{-2 \mu_{+} x}}{(1+\beta) \mu_{+}-(1-\beta) \mu_{-}}, & x>0\end{cases}
$$

Proof. For $x<0<b$, by Theorem 2 we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
\mathbb{P}_{x}\left(\sup _{0<t<\infty} X_{t} \geq b\right) & =\mathbb{P}_{x}\left(\tau_{b}<\infty\right)=\lim _{q \rightarrow 0+} \mathbb{E}_{x}\left[e^{-q \tau_{b}}\right] \\
& =\lim _{q \rightarrow 0} \frac{e^{\mu_{+}^{-} x}}{\left(1-c_{2}(q)\right) e^{\mu_{+}^{+} b}+c_{2}(q) e^{\mu_{+}^{+} b}} \\
& =\frac{(1+\beta) \mu_{+} e^{-2 \mu_{-} x}}{(1+\beta) \mu_{+}-(1-\beta) \mu_{-}+(1-\beta) \mu_{-} e^{-2 \mu_{+} b}}
\end{aligned}
$$

Then

$$
\mathbb{P}_{x}\left(\sup _{0<t<\infty} X_{t}=\infty\right)=\lim _{b \rightarrow \infty} \mathbb{P}_{x}\left(\sup _{0<t<\infty} X_{t} \geq b\right)=\frac{(1+\beta) \mu_{+} e^{-2 \mu_{-} x}}{(1+\beta) \mu_{+}-(1-\beta) \mu_{-}}
$$

Similarly, for $0<x<b$,

$$
\begin{aligned}
\mathbb{P}_{x}\left(\sup _{0<t<\infty} X_{t} \geq b\right) & =\mathbb{P}_{x}\left(\tau_{b}<\infty\right)=\lim _{q \rightarrow 0+} \mathbb{E}_{x}\left[e^{-q \tau_{b}}\right] \\
& =\lim _{q \rightarrow 0} \frac{\left(1-c_{2}(q)\right) e^{\rho_{2}^{\tau_{x}}} x+c_{2}(q) e^{\rho_{1}^{\tau_{x}}} x}{\left(1-c_{2}(q)\right) e^{\rho_{2}^{\tau_{b}}} x+c_{2}(q) e^{\rho_{1}^{\tau_{b}}} x} \\
& =\frac{(1+\beta) \mu_{+}-(1-\beta) \mu_{-}+(1-\beta) \mu_{-} e^{-2 \mu_{+} x}}{(1+\beta) \mu_{+}-(1-\beta) \mu_{-}+(1-\beta) \mu_{-} e^{-2 \mu_{+} b}}
\end{aligned}
$$

Then

$$
\mathbb{P}_{x}\left(\sup _{0<t<\infty} X_{t}=\infty\right)=\lim _{b \rightarrow \infty} \mathbb{P}_{x}\left(\sup _{0<t<\infty} X_{t} \geq b\right)=\frac{(1+\beta) \mu_{+}-(1-\beta) \mu_{-}+(1-\beta) \mu_{-} e^{-2 \mu_{+} x}}{(1+\beta) \mu_{+}-(1-\beta) \mu_{-}}
$$

For $b \leq 0 \leq x$,

$$
\begin{aligned}
\mathbb{P}_{x}\left(\inf _{0<t<\infty} X_{t} \leq b\right) & =\mathbb{P}_{x}\left(\tau_{b}<\infty\right)=\lim _{q \rightarrow 0-} \mathbb{E}_{x}\left[e^{-q \tau_{b}}\right] \\
& =\lim _{q \rightarrow 0} \frac{e^{\rho_{1}^{\tau_{x}}}}{c_{1}(q) e^{\rho_{2}^{\tau_{x}} b}+\left(1-c_{1}(q)\right) e^{\rho_{1}^{\tau_{b}}} b} \\
& =\frac{-(1-\beta) \mu_{-} e^{-2 \mu_{+} x}}{-(1+\beta) \mu_{+} e^{-2 \mu_{-} b}+(1+\beta) \mu_{+}-(1-\beta) \mu_{-}}
\end{aligned}
$$

It follows that

$$
\mathbb{P}_{x}\left(\inf _{0<t<\infty} X_{t}=-\infty\right)=\lim _{b \rightarrow-\infty} \mathbb{P}_{x}\left(\inf _{0<t<\infty} X_{t} \leq b\right)=\frac{-(1-\beta) \mu_{-} e^{-2 \mu_{+} x}}{(1+\beta) \mu_{+}-(1-\beta) \mu_{-}}
$$

For $b \leq x \leq 0$,

$$
\begin{aligned}
\mathbb{P}_{x}\left(\inf _{0<t<\infty} X_{t} \leq b\right) & =\mathbb{P}_{x}\left(\tau_{b}<\infty\right)=\lim _{q \rightarrow 0^{-}} \mathbb{E}_{x}\left[e^{-q \tau_{b}}\right] \\
& =\lim _{q \rightarrow 0} \frac{c_{1}(q) e^{\rho_{2}^{\tau_{x}}} x+\left(1-c_{1}(q)\right) e^{\rho_{1}^{\tau_{x}}} x}{c_{1}(q) e^{\rho_{2}^{\tau_{b}} b}+\left(1-c_{1}(q)\right) e^{\rho_{1}^{\tau_{b}}} b} \\
& =\frac{-(1+\beta) \mu_{+} e^{-2 \mu_{-} x}+(1+\beta) \mu_{+}-(1-\beta) \mu_{-}}{-(1+\beta) \mu_{+} e^{-2 \mu_{-} b}+(1+\beta) \mu_{+}-(1-\beta) \mu_{-}}
\end{aligned}
$$

So,

$$
\mathbb{P}_{x}\left(\inf _{0<t<\infty} X_{t}=-\infty\right)=\lim _{b \rightarrow-\infty} \mathbb{P}_{x}\left(\inf _{0<t<\infty} X_{t} \leq b\right)=\frac{(1+\beta) \mu_{+}-(1-\beta) \mu_{-}-(1+\beta) \mu_{+} e^{-2 \mu_{-} x}}{(1+\beta) \mu_{+}-(1-\beta) \mu_{-}}
$$

Proposition 8. For $\mu_{-}>0, \mu_{+}<0$ and any real value $x, z$, we have $\mathbb{P}_{x}\left(\tau_{z}<\infty\right)=1$.
Proof. We follow an argument similar to that in Proposition (7) but for $\mu_{-}>0$ and $\mu_{+}<0$. For $x<0<z$,

$$
\mathbb{P}_{x}\left(\tau_{z}<\infty\right)=\lim _{q \rightarrow 0+} \mathbb{E}_{x}\left[e^{-q \tau_{z}}\right]=\lim _{q \rightarrow 0} \frac{e^{\rho_{2}^{\tau_{x}}}}{1-c_{2}(q)) e^{\rho_{2}^{\tau_{x}}} x+c_{2}(q) e^{\rho_{1}^{\tau_{x}}}}=1
$$

for $0<x<z$,

$$
\mathbb{P}_{x}\left(\tau_{z}<\infty\right)=\lim _{q \rightarrow 0+} \mathbb{E}_{x}\left[e^{-q \tau_{z}}\right]=\lim _{q \rightarrow 0} \frac{\left(1-c_{2}(q)\right) e^{\rho_{2}^{\tau_{x}}} x+c_{2}(q) e^{\rho_{1}^{\tau_{x}}}}{\left(1-c_{2}(q)\right) e^{\rho_{2}^{\tau_{x}}} x+c_{2}(q) e^{\rho_{1}^{\tau_{x}}}}=1
$$

for $z \leq 0 \leq x$,

$$
\mathbb{P}_{x}\left(\tau_{z}<\infty\right)=\lim _{q \rightarrow 0-} \mathbb{E}_{x}\left[e^{-q \tau_{z}}\right]=\lim _{q \rightarrow 0} \frac{e^{\rho_{1}^{+} x}}{c_{1}(q) e^{\rho_{2}^{-} z}+\left(1-c_{1}(q)\right) e^{\rho_{1}^{-} z}}=1
$$

and for $z \leq x \leq 0$,

$$
\mathbb{P}_{x}\left(\tau_{z}<\infty\right)=\lim _{q \rightarrow 0-} \mathbb{E}_{x}\left[e^{-q \tau_{z}}\right]=\lim _{q \rightarrow 0} \frac{c_{1}(q) e^{\rho_{2}^{-} x}+\left(1-c_{1}(q)\right) e^{\rho_{1}^{-} x}}{c_{1}(q) e^{\rho_{2}^{-} z}+\left(1-c_{1}(q)\right) e^{\rho_{1}^{-} z}}=1
$$

Note that for $\mu_{-}>0$ and $\mu_{+}<0$, as $q \rightarrow 0$ both $c_{1}(q)$ and $c_{2}(q)$ tend to 1 , and $\rho_{1}^{-}, \rho_{2}^{-}, \rho_{1}^{+}, \rho_{2}^{+}$tends to $-2 \mu_{-}, 0,0$, $-2 \mu_{+}$, respectively.

Proposition 9. Given any real value $x, z, \mathbb{E}_{x}\left(\tau_{z}\right)<\infty$ for $\mu_{-}>0$ and $\mu_{+}<0$, and it is infinite if either $\mu_{+}=0$ or $\mu_{-}=0$.

Proof. According to Theorem (2), if we define $\psi(q)=\mathbb{E}_{x}\left[e^{-q \tau_{z}}\right]$, then $\mathbb{E}_{x}\left[\tau_{z}\right]=-\psi^{\prime}(0)$. Given $\mu_{-}>0$ and $\mu_{+}<0$, when $x<0<z$,

$$
\mathbb{E}_{x}\left[\tau_{z}\right]=\frac{2(1+\beta)\left(\mu_{-} \mu_{+} z-\mu_{+}^{2} x\right)+\left(\mu_{-}(1+\beta)-\mu_{+}(1-\beta)\right)\left(e^{-2 \mu_{+} z}-1\right)}{2 \mu_{-} \mu_{+}^{2}(1+\beta)}
$$

when $0<x<z$,

$$
\mathbb{E}_{x}\left[\tau_{z}\right]=\frac{2(1+\beta) \mu_{-} \mu_{+}(z-x)+\left(\mu_{-}(1+\beta)-\mu_{+}(1-\beta)\right)\left(e^{-2 \mu_{+} z}-e^{-2 \mu_{+} x}\right)}{2 \mu_{-} \mu_{+}^{2}(1+\beta)}
$$

when $z \leq 0 \leq x$,

$$
\mathbb{E}_{x}\left[\tau_{z}\right]=\frac{2(1-\beta)\left(\mu_{-} \mu_{+} z-\mu_{-}^{2} x\right)+\left(\mu_{-}(1+\beta)-\mu_{+}(1-\beta)\right)\left(1-e^{-2 \mu_{-} z}\right)}{2 \mu_{-}^{2} \mu_{+}(1-\beta)}
$$

and when $z \leq x \leq 0$,

$$
\mathbb{E}_{x}\left[\tau_{z}\right]=\frac{2 \mu_{-} \mu_{+}(1-\beta)(z-x)+\left(\mu_{-}(1+\beta)-\mu_{+}(1-\beta)\right)\left(e^{-2 \mu_{-} x}-e^{-2 \mu_{-} z}\right)}{2 \mu_{-}^{2} \mu_{+}(1-\beta)}
$$

The desired results then follow.

# VI Approximation and Simulation 

As mentioned in the introduction, skew Brownian motion has many applications across various fields. A key aspect of these applications is the generation of samples from the distribution, which can be utilized in Monte Carlo simulations. However, due to the complexity of the stochastic differential equation (SDE) governing SBM and the intricate nature of its cumulative distribution function (CDF), traditional methods such as the Euler scheme or transformation methods are challenging to implement.
Although SBM does not have the independent increments because it is biased at the skew level, we can approximate its CDF on either side of the skew level; here is zero. In this section, we introduce two methods to generate quasirandom samples of skew Brownian motion. The first method approximates the CDF of SBM using a truncated normal distribution and then generates random samples based on the inverse of this approximated CDF. The second method employs a deep neural network to approximate the inverse of the CDF of SBM, subsequently generating random samples using the trained network.

## VI. 1 Using Truncated Normal Distribution

A truncated normal distribution is a modification of the normal (Gaussian) distribution where values below a certain lower bound and/or above a certain upper bound are excluded, or "truncated." This results in a distribution that is confined to a specified range. The truncation can occur on either one side (left or right) or on both sides of the distribution. Suppose $X$ is a normal random variable with mean $\mu$ and variance $\sigma^{2}$, with probability density function $f(x)$ and cumulative distribution function $F(x)$. Then the PDF, $k(x)$, and CDF, $K(x)$, of the normal distribution truncated in $[a, b]$ is given by:

$$
k(x)=\frac{f(x)}{F(b)-F(a)}, \quad K(x)=\frac{F(x)-F(a)}{F(b)-F(a)}
$$

Suppose $X=\left(X_{t}\right)_{t \geq 0}$ is the refracted skew Brownian motion, with skew level $a=0$ and starting point $x=0$ with the CDF given in Proposition (3). Given that the density function of $X$ on either side of the skew level closely resembles a normal distribution, we assume that $X$ is a truncated Brownian motion. So we approximate the CDF of RSBM with the following mixture of truncated normal distributions:

$$
H(x)= \begin{cases}\alpha K_{1}(x), & x<0 \\ \alpha+(1-\alpha) K_{2}(x), & x>0\end{cases}
$$

where $K_{1}(x)=\frac{F(x)}{F(0)}$ is the CDF of a truncated normal variable in support $(-\infty, 0)$, and $K_{2}(x)=\frac{G(x)-G(0)}{1-G(0)}$ is the CDF of a truncated normal variable in support $(0, \infty)$. Here, $F$ is a normal CDF with mean $\mu_{1}$, variance $\sigma_{1}^{2}$ and $G$ is the normal CDF with mean $\mu_{2}$, variance $\sigma_{2}^{2}$, and $\alpha$ is a constant in $[0,1]$.
Given the parameters $\alpha, \mu_{1}, \sigma_{1}^{2}, \mu_{2}, \sigma_{2}^{2}$ of $H$, we can generate random samples of the RSBM by transforming uniform random variables using the inverse CDF method. For a uniform random variable $u$, the quasi-random sample RSBM is given by:

$$
\hat{X}= \begin{cases}F^{-1}\left(\frac{u}{\alpha} F(0)\right), & u \leq \alpha \\ G^{-1}\left(\frac{u-\alpha}{1-\alpha}(1-G(0))+G(0)\right), & u>\alpha\end{cases}
$$

The remaining task is to determine the parameters of $H$. To achieve an accurate approximation, we use the Sequential Least Squares Programming (SLSQP) method [26] in the SciPy Python package. This optimization technique is employed to minimize the quantile of absolute errors between the RSBM CDF and $H$. Algorithm (1) outlines the necessary steps to generate random samples of RSBM using a mixture truncated normal distribution.

```
Algorithm 1 RSBM Quasi-Random Sample Generation Using Truncated Normal Distribution
Require: \(\mathbf{x}\) : Vector of equispaced or non-equispaced values in the interval \([-A, A]\) with length \(N\),
    params: Skew Brownian Motion parameters
Ensure: \(\hat{X}\) : Random sample of RSBM
    Calculate \(\mathbb{P}\left(X \leq x_{i}\right)\) for each \(i \in\{1, \ldots, N\}\) based on Proposition (3),
    Estimate parameters \(\mu_{1}, \sigma_{1}, \mu_{2}, \sigma_{2}, \alpha\) of the mixture truncated normal distribution by:
```

$$
\min _{i} Q_{0.99}\left(\left|\mathbb{P}\left(X \leq x_{i}\right)-H\left(x_{i}\right)\right|\right)
$$

Generate uniform random variables $u$,
Generate RSBM random samples $\hat{X}$ using the approximated mixture truncated normal distribution as per equation (22).

# VI. 2 Using Deep Neural Network 

A deep neural network (DNN) is a type of artificial neural network (ANN) with multiple layers between the input and output layers. These additional layers, often referred to as hidden layers, enable the network to model complex, hierarchical patterns in data. DNNs are a core component of deep learning, a subset of machine learning, and have many applications in computer vision, finance, games, etc. Researchers have shared an immense interest in applying neural networks to generate quasi-random samples from a distribution. For instance, Horger et al. in [21] introduced a neural network model capable of transforming samples from a uniform distribution into samples of any specified probability density function. Hofert et al. in [20] presented a new approach for generating quasi-random samples from multivariate distributions with any underlying copula using generative neural networks. Furthermore, Gibson et al. in [18] proposed a method that employs Normalizing Flow generative models combined with Importance Sampling to simulate samples from rare event distributions and achieve accurate estimates. Here, we use DNN to approximate the inverse of CDF of an RSBM, then generate quasi-random samples using the trained network. Since deep neural networks (DNNs) are not the main focus of this paper, we will not delve into their details. Instead, we will briefly explain our algorithm and leave the rest to readers to explore further as needed.
Algorithm (2) explains the steps for training the neural network and generating random sample variables of RSBM. We use one node in both the input and output layers and employ four hidden layers with $512,1025,512$, and 1024 nodes, respectively. Additionally, we utilize the Adam optimization algorithm. The number of epochs and iterations are 10,000 and 250 respectively.

```
Algorithm 2 RSBM Quasi-Random Sample Generation Using DNN
Require: \(z\) : Equispaced or non-equispaced values in the interval \([-A, A]\),
    params: Skew Brownian Motion parameters
Ensure: \(\check{Z}\) : Random sample of RSBM
    Calculate \(F(z)=\mathbb{P}(Z \leq z)\) based on Proposition (3).
    for epochs do
        for Iterations do
            Get a chunk of \(F(z)\)
            Calculate the \(\check{z}=F^{-1}(F(z))\) using the neural network
            Calculate the objective function (Means Absolute Error \(=\sum_{i}\left|z_{i}-\check{z}_{i}\right|\)
            Update the neural network weights using back-propagation and auto-gradient
        end for
    end for
    Generate uniform random variables \(u\)
    Generate RSBM random samples \(\check{Z}\) using trained neural network and \(u\) as its input.
```

# VI. 3 Simulation Results 

In this section, we generate random samples of RSBM with different parameters using the two above-mentioned methods. In order to test the goodness-of-fit of generated random models, we employ a one-sample Kolmogorov-Smirnov (K-S) test. KS test is a nonparametric test to determine whether a sample comes from a specified continuous distribution. The Kolmogorov-Smirnov statistic quantifies the distance between the empirical distribution function of the sample and the cumulative distribution function of the reference distribution. The null distribution of this statistic is calculated under the null hypothesis that the sample is drawn from the reference distribution. Since the RSBM CDF is a right-continuous distribution with a single jump at the skew level, we can use a one-sample K-S test to determine whether the generated quasi-random samples follow the same distribution as the RSBM.
We consider four models for RSBM with different parameters (Table 1) and utilize the approximation methods to generate random samples. In addition, we consider $A=20$ in both Algorithms (1 and 2).

## VI. 4 Application in Risk Measurement

The RSBM provides a versatile and powerful tool for modeling various asymmetric behaviors in financial markets. By incorporating skewness, it allows for more accurate pricing, risk management, and strategic decision-making, reflecting the true nature of financial assets and market dynamics. In markets, assets often have returns that are not symmetrically distributed. RSBM can better capture the empirical characteristics of asset returns, providing more realistic pricing and risk management models [4]. In addition, Investors with preferences for or against skewness in returns can benefit

Table 2: K-S Test Results for DNN and TNA Methods Across Different Models
![img-0.jpeg](img-0.jpeg)

Figure 1: Histogram and CDF of generated random samples for different models with deep neural network against the exact PDF and CDF of the model
from portfolio optimization models incorporating skew Brownian motion. This allows for more tailored portfolio construction, balancing risk and return according to the investor's skewness preferences. In the risk assessment aspect, conventional risk measures such as Value-at-Risk (VaR) and Conditional Value-at-Risk (CVaR) can be adapted to account for skewness in the underlying return distributions, providing more accurate assessments of downside risk.

Calculating risk measures like VaR and CVaR based on the theoretical CDF of RSBM is challenging. Therefore, we use the truncated normal approximation (described in the previous section) to evaluate these risk measures based on the estimated parameters. Let $L$ be the loss in a portfolio that follows an RSBM, for a confidence level $q, \operatorname{VaR}_{q}(L)$ defined as:

$$
\mathbb{P}\left(L \geq \operatorname{VaR}_{q}(L)\right)=1-q
$$

One can easily calculate the VaR based on estimated parameters of mixed truncated normal approximation with:

$$
\operatorname{VaR}_{q}(L)= \begin{cases}\mu_{1}+\sigma_{1} \Phi^{-1}\left(\frac{q}{\alpha} \Phi\left(\frac{-\mu_{1}}{\sigma_{1}}\right)\right), & q \leq \alpha \\ \mu_{2}+\sigma_{2} \Phi^{-1}\left(\frac{q-\alpha}{1-\alpha}+\frac{1-q}{1-\alpha} \Phi\left(\frac{-\mu_{2}}{\sigma_{2}}\right)\right), & q>\alpha\end{cases}
$$

![img-1.jpeg](img-1.jpeg)

Figure 2: Histogram and CDF of generated random samples for different models with truncated Normal approximation against the exact PDF and CDF of the model

Since the VaR of loss values is a positive value, the CVaR can be calculated as follows:

$$
\begin{aligned}
\operatorname{CVaR}_{q}(L)=\mathbb{E}\left[L \mid L \geq \operatorname{VaR}_{q}(L)\right] & =\frac{1}{1-q} \int_{\mathrm{VaR}_{q}(L)}^{\infty} x h(x) \mathrm{d} x \\
& =\frac{1}{1-q} \int_{\mathrm{VaR}_{q}(L)}^{\infty} \frac{1-\alpha}{1-G(0)} x g(x) \mathrm{d} x \\
& =\frac{1-\alpha}{\left(1-\Phi\left(\frac{-\mu_{2}}{\sigma_{2}}\right)\right)(1-q)} \int_{\mathrm{VaR}_{q}(L)}^{\infty} x g(x) \mathrm{d} x \\
& =\mu_{2}+\frac{\sigma_{2}(1-\alpha)}{\left(1-\Phi\left(\frac{-\mu_{2}}{\sigma_{2}}\right)\right)(1-q)} \phi\left(\Phi^{-1}\left(\frac{q-\alpha}{1-\alpha}+\frac{1-q}{1-\alpha} \Phi\left(\frac{-\mu_{2}}{\sigma_{2}}\right)\right)\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

We utilize Model 2 in Table (1) to evaluate the accuracy of the approximated VaR and CVaR. First, we compute the CDF of the RSBM using 2500 data points from the interval $[-20,20]$. We next calculate the VaR using the linear interpolation method on the CDF and data points. We then use the estimated parameters of the mixed truncated distribution to approximate the VaR and CVaR. Finally, we run 100,000 quasi-random samples through the historical Monte Carlo simulation to calculate the VaR and CVaR for different confidence levels greater than $\alpha=0.2569$ which acts like a border to have positive VaR. Note that we do not report negative VaR and CVaR because negative loss is not considered a risk.

Figure (3) presents the graph of estimated VaR and CVaR using the formulas in (23) and (24), as well as the historical Monte Carlo simulation. This plot compares the precision of the approximated value of risk to the semi-exact values, which are displayed in black. The mean square of errors of approximated VaR and Monte-Carlo VaR are 0.000019 and 0.000025 respectively.

# A Proof of Corollary 4.1 

For $\mu_{-}=\mu_{+}=\mu$ and $y>0$,

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \mathbb{P}\left(X_{t} \in \mathrm{~d} y\right) \\
= & 2(1+\beta) e^{2 \mu y} \int_{0}^{\infty} \int_{0}^{t} h(t-\tau ;(1+\beta) b+y, \mu) h(\tau ;(1-\beta) b,-\mu) \mathrm{d} \tau \mathrm{~d} b \mathrm{~d} y \\
= & 2(1+\beta) e^{2 \mu y} \int_{0}^{\infty} \int_{0}^{t} h(t-\tau ;(1+\beta) b+y, \mu) h(\tau ;(1-\beta) b, \mu) e^{2 \mu(1-\beta) b} \mathrm{~d} \tau \mathrm{~d} b \mathrm{~d} y \\
= & 2(1+\beta) e^{2 \mu y} \int_{0}^{\infty} e^{2 \mu(1-\beta) b} h(t ; y+2 b, \mu) \mathrm{d} b d y \\
= & \frac{2(1+\beta)}{\sqrt{2 \pi t^{3}}} e^{2 \mu y} \int_{0}^{\infty} e^{2 \mu(1-\beta) b}(y+2 b) e^{\frac{-(y+2 b+\mu t)^{2}}{2 t}} \mathrm{~d} b \mathrm{~d} y \\
= & \frac{2(1+\beta)}{\sqrt{2 \pi t^{3}}} e^{2 \mu y} e^{\frac{-(y+\mu t)^{2}}{2 t}} e^{\frac{(y+\beta \mu t)^{2}}{2 t}} \int_{0}^{\infty}(y+2 b) e^{\frac{-(2 b+y+\beta \mu t)^{2}}{2 t}} \mathrm{~d} b \mathrm{~d} y \\
= & \frac{2(1+\beta)}{\sqrt{2 \pi t^{3}}} e^{\frac{-(y-\mu t)^{2}}{2 t}} e^{\frac{(y+\beta \mu t)^{2}}{2 t}}\left[\int_{0}^{\infty}(y+2 b+\beta \mu t) e^{\frac{-(2 b+y+\beta \mu t)^{2}}{2 t}} \mathrm{~d} b-\beta \mu t \int_{0}^{\infty} e^{\frac{-(2 b+y+\beta \mu t)^{2}}{2 t}} \mathrm{~d} b\right] \mathrm{d} y \\
= & \frac{(1+\beta)}{\sqrt{2 \pi t^{3}}} e^{\frac{-(y-\mu t)^{2}}{2 t}} e^{\frac{(y+\beta \mu t)^{2}}{2 t}}\left[\int_{y}^{\infty}(v+\beta \mu t) e^{\frac{-(v+\beta \mu t)^{2}}{2 t}} \mathrm{~d} v-\beta \mu t \int_{y}^{\infty} e^{\frac{-(v+\beta \mu t)^{2}}{2 t}} \mathrm{~d} v\right] \mathrm{d} y \\
= & \frac{(1+\beta)}{\sqrt{2 \pi t}} e^{\frac{-(y-\mu t)^{2}}{2 t}} e^{\frac{(y+\beta \mu t)^{2}}{2 t}}\left[e^{\frac{-(y+\beta \mu t)^{2}}{2 t}}-\frac{\beta \mu}{2} \sqrt{2 \pi t} \operatorname{erfc}\left(\frac{y+\beta \mu t}{\sqrt{2 t}}\right)\right] \mathrm{d} y \\
= & \frac{(1+\beta)}{\sqrt{2 \pi t}} e^{\frac{-(y-\mu t)^{2}}{2 t}}\left[1-\frac{\beta \mu}{2} \sqrt{2 \pi t} e^{\frac{(y+\beta \mu t)^{2}}{2 t}} \operatorname{erfc}\left(\frac{y+\beta \mu t}{\sqrt{2 t}}\right)\right] \mathrm{d} y
\end{aligned}
$$

For $\mu_{-}=\mu_{+}=\mu$ and $y<0$,

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \mathbb{P}\left(X_{t} \in \mathrm{~d} y\right) \\
= & 2(1-\beta) e^{2 \mu y} \int_{0}^{\infty} \int_{0}^{t} h(t-\tau ;(1+\beta) b, \mu) h(\tau ;(1-\beta) b-y,-\mu) \mathrm{d} \tau \mathrm{~d} b d y \\
= & 2(1-\beta) e^{2 \mu y} \int_{0}^{\infty} \int_{0}^{t} h(t-\tau ;(1+\beta) b,-\mu) h(\tau ;(1-\beta) b-y,-\mu) e^{-2 \mu(1+\beta) b} \mathrm{~d} \tau \mathrm{~d} b \mathrm{~d} y \\
= & 2(1-\beta) e^{2 \mu y} \int_{0}^{\infty} e^{-2 \mu(1+\beta) b} h(t ;-y+2 b,-\mu) \mathrm{d} b \mathrm{~d} y \\
= & \frac{2(1-\beta)}{\sqrt{2 \pi t^{3}}} e^{2 \mu y} \int_{0}^{\infty} e^{-2 \mu(1+\beta) b}(-y+2 b) e^{\frac{-(-y+2 b-\mu t)^{2}}{2 t}} \mathrm{~d} b \mathrm{~d} y \\
= & \frac{2(1-\beta)}{\sqrt{2 \pi t^{3}}} e^{2 \mu y} e^{\frac{-(y+\mu t)^{2}}{2 t}} e^{\frac{(-y+\beta \mu t)^{2}}{2 t}} \int_{0}^{\infty}(-y+2 b) e^{\frac{-(-y+2 b+\beta \mu t)^{2}}{2 t}} \mathrm{~d} b d y \\
= & \frac{2(1-\beta)}{\sqrt{2 \pi t^{3}}} e^{\frac{-(y-\mu t)^{2}}{2 t}} e^{\frac{(-y+\beta \mu t)^{2}}{2 t}}\left[\int_{0}^{\infty}(-y+2 b+\beta \mu t) e^{\frac{(-y+2 b+\beta \mu t)^{2}}{2 t}} \mathrm{~d} b-\beta \mu t \int_{0}^{\infty} e^{\frac{-(-y+2 b+\beta \mu t)^{2}}{2 t}} \mathrm{~d} b\right] \mathrm{d} y \\
= & \frac{(1-\beta)}{\sqrt{2 \pi t^{3}}} e^{\frac{-(y-\mu t)^{2}}{2 t}} e^{\frac{(-y+\beta \mu t)^{2}}{2 t}}\left[\int_{-y}^{\infty}(v+\beta \mu t) e^{\frac{-(v+\beta \mu t)^{2}}{2 t}} \mathrm{~d} v-\beta \mu t \int_{-y}^{\infty} e^{\frac{-(v+\beta \mu t)^{2}}{2 t}} \mathrm{~d} v\right] \mathrm{d} y \\
= & \frac{(1-\beta)}{\sqrt{2 \pi t}} e^{\frac{-(y-\mu t)^{2}}{2 t}} e^{\frac{(-y+\beta \mu t)^{2}}{2 t}}\left[e^{\frac{-(-y+\beta \mu t)^{2}}{2 t}}-\frac{\beta \mu}{2} \sqrt{2 \pi t} \operatorname{erfc}\left(\frac{-y+\beta \mu t}{\sqrt{2 t}}\right)\right] \mathrm{d} y \\
= & \frac{(1-\beta)}{\sqrt{2 \pi t}} e^{\frac{-(y-\mu t)^{2}}{2 t}}\left[1-\frac{\beta \mu}{2} \sqrt{2 \pi t} e^{\frac{(-y+\beta \mu t)^{2}}{2 t}} \operatorname{erfc}\left(\frac{-y+\beta \mu t}{\sqrt{2 t}}\right)\right] \mathrm{d} y
\end{aligned}
$$

Remark 4. By formula 183 in the table 2.3 in [1], and a property of Laplace transform one can show that

$$

which is equivalent to formulas 1.0 .5 and 1.0 .6 in [9].
