& =2(1-\beta) e^{2 \mu-y} f^{-}(t ; y) * h\left(t ; x, \mu_{+}\right) \\
& =2(1-\beta) e^{2 \mu-y} \int_{0}^{t} f^{-}(\eta ; y) h\left(t-\eta ; x, \mu_{+}\right) \mathrm{d} \eta \\
& =2(1-\beta) e^{2 \mu-y} \int_{0}^{\infty} \int_{0}^{t} \int_{0}^{\eta} h\left(\eta-\tau ;(1+\beta) b, \mu_{+}\right) h\left(\tau ;(1-\beta) b-y,-\mu_{-}\right) h\left(t-\eta ; x, \mu_{+}\right) \mathrm{d} \tau \mathrm{~d} \eta \mathrm{~d} b \\
& =2(1-\beta) e^{2 \mu-y} \int_{0}^{\infty} \int_{0}^{t} h\left(\tau ;(1-\beta) b-y,-\mu_{-}\right) \int_{\tau}^{t} h\left(\eta-\tau ;(1+\beta) b, \mu_{+}\right) h\left(t-\eta ; x, \mu_{+}\right) \mathrm{d} \eta \mathrm{~d} \tau \mathrm{~d} b \\
& =2(1-\beta) e^{2 \mu-y} \int_{0}^{\infty} \int_{0}^{t} h\left(\tau ;(1-\beta) b-y,-\mu_{-}\right) \int_{0}^{t-\tau} h\left(t-\tau-u ;(1+\beta) b, \mu_{+}\right) h\left(u ; x, \mu_{+}\right) \mathrm{d} u \mathrm{~d} \tau \mathrm{~d} b \\
& =2(1-\beta) e^{2 \mu-y} \int_{0}^{\infty} \int_{0}^{t} h\left(t-\tau ;(1+\beta) b+x, \mu_{+}\right) h\left(\tau ;(1-\beta) b-y,-\mu_{-}\right) \mathrm{d} \tau \mathrm{~d} b
\end{aligned}
$$

where we change the order of integrals in the fifth equality and use changing the variable $u=t-\eta$ in the sixth equality. For $y<0$ and $x \leq 0$,

$$
\begin{aligned}
p(x, y, t) & =\mathcal{L}^{-1}\left\{\mathbb{P}_{x}\left(X_{e_{q}} \in \mathrm{~d} y\right)\right\} \\
& =e^{\mu_{-}(y-x)}\left[\phi\left(y-x ; \mu_{-}\right) e^{-\mu_{-}(y-x)}-\phi\left(-x-y ; \mu_{-}\right) e^{\mu_{-}(x+y)}\right]+2(1-\beta) e^{2 \mu_{-} y} f^{-}(t ; y) * h\left(t ;-x, \mu_{-}\right) e^{-2 \mu_{-} x} \\
& =\phi\left(y-x ; \mu_{-}\right)-e^{2 \mu-y} \phi\left(-x-y ; \mu_{-}\right)+2(1-\beta) e^{2 \mu-y} f^{-}(t ; y) * h\left(t ;-x,-\mu_{-}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

For the last term:

$$
\begin{aligned}
& 2(1-\beta) e^{2 \mu-y} \int_{0}^{t} f^{-}(\eta ; y) h\left(t-\eta ;-x,-\mu_{-}\right) \mathrm{d} \eta \\
= & 2(1-\beta) e^{2 \mu-y} \int_{0}^{\infty} \int_{0}^{t} \int_{0}^{\eta} h\left(\tau ;(1+\beta) b, \mu_{+}\right) h\left(\eta-\tau ;(1-\beta) b-y,-\mu_{-}\right) h\left(t-\eta ;-x,-\mu_{-}\right) \mathrm{d} \tau \mathrm{~d} \eta \mathrm{~d} b \\
= & 2(1-\beta) e^{2 \mu-y} \int_{0}^{\infty} \int_{0}^{t} h\left(\tau ;(1+\beta) b, \mu_{+}\right) \int_{\tau}^{t} h\left(\eta-\tau ;(1-\beta) b-y,-\mu_{-}\right) h\left(t-\eta ;-x,-\mu_{-}\right) \mathrm{d} \eta \mathrm{~d} \tau \mathrm{~d} b \\
= & 2(1-\beta) e^{2 \mu-y} \int_{0}^{\infty} \int_{0}^{t} h\left(\tau ;(1+\beta) b, \mu_{+}\right) \int_{0}^{t-\tau} h\left(t-\tau-u ;(1-\beta) b-y,-\mu_{-}\right) h\left(u ;-x,-\mu_{-}\right) \mathrm{d} u \mathrm{~d} \tau \mathrm{~d} b \\
= & 2(1-\beta) e^{2 \mu-y} \int_{0}^{\infty} \int_{0}^{t} h\left(\tau ;(1+\beta) b, \mu_{+}\right) h\left(t-\tau ;(1-\beta) b-y-x,-\mu_{-}\right) \mathrm{d} \tau \mathrm{~d} b
\end{aligned}
$$

where we change the order of $\tau$ and $\eta$ in the second equality and use changing variable $u=t-\eta$ in the third equality. So,

$$
\begin{aligned}
p(x, y, t)= & \phi\left(y-x ; \mu_{-}\right)-e^{2 \mu-y} \phi\left(-x-y ; \mu_{-}\right) \\
& +2(1-\beta) e^{2 \mu-y} \int_{0}^{\infty} \int_{0}^{t} h\left(\tau ;(1+\beta) b, \mu_{+}\right) h\left(t-\tau ;(1-\beta) b-y-x,-\mu_{-}\right) \mathrm{d} \tau \mathrm{~d} b
\end{aligned}
$$

# C Remarks on the joint density in Gairat and Shcherbakov [15]
## Based on equation (2.3) in their paper

In [15] the following joint density of the refracted skew Brownian motion $X_{T}$, its last visit to the origin $\tau$, occupation time $V$, and local times $L_{T}^{(0)}(X)$ is given in (2.3), where $T$ is time.

For $0 \leq v \leq t \leq T, l \geq 0$,

$$
\phi_{T}(t, v, x, l)= \begin{cases}2 p h^{\prime}(v, l p) h^{\prime}(t-v, l q) h^{\prime}(T-t, x) e^{-\frac{m_{2}^{2} v}{2}-\frac{m_{2}^{2}(T-v)}{2}-l\left(m_{1} p-q m_{2}\right)+m_{1} x}, & x>0 \\ 2 q h^{\prime}(v, l p) h^{\prime}(t-v, l q) h^{\prime}(T-t, x) e^{-\frac{m_{2}^{2} v}{2}-\frac{m_{2}^{2}(T-v)}{2}-l\left(m_{1} p-q m_{2}\right)+m_{2} x}, & x<0\end{cases}
$$

where $h^{\prime}(s ; y)=\frac{|y|}{\sqrt{2 \pi s^{2}}} e^{\frac{-y^{2}}{2 s}}, p=1-q$ and $m_{1}$ and $m_{2}$ correspond to $\mu_{-}$and $\mu_{+}$respectively in our notation. We can write function $h$ in (17) as $h(s ; y, \mu)=h^{\prime}(s ; y) e^{-\frac{s^{2}}{2} s} e^{-\mu y}$.
Now, let's find the marginal distribution of $X_{T}$, for $x>0$ :

$$
\begin{aligned}
\mathbb{P}_{T}(x) & =\int_{0}^{\infty} \int_{0}^{T} \int_{0}^{t} \phi_{T}(t, v, x, l) \mathrm{d} v \mathrm{~d} t \mathrm{~d} l \\
& =\int_{0}^{\infty} \int_{0}^{T} \int_{0}^{t} 2 p h^{\prime}(v, l p) h^{\prime}(t-v, l q) h^{\prime}(T-t, x) e^{-\frac{m_{2}^{2} v}{2}-\frac{m_{2}^{2}(T-v)}{2}-l\left(m_{1} p-q m_{2}\right)+m_{1} x} \mathrm{~d} v \mathrm{~d} t \mathrm{~d} l \\
& =2 p e^{m_{1} x} \int_{0}^{\infty} \int_{0}^{T} \int_{0}^{t} h^{\prime}(v, l p) e^{-\frac{m_{2}^{2} v}{2}} e^{-m_{1} l p} h^{\prime}(t-v, l q) h^{\prime}(T-t, x) e^{-\frac{m_{2}^{2}(T-t+t-v)}{2}+m_{2} l q} \mathrm{~d} v \mathrm{~d} t \mathrm{~d} l \\
& =2 p e^{m_{1} x} \int_{0}^{\infty} \int_{0}^{T} \int_{0}^{t} h^{\prime}(v, l p) e^{-\frac{m_{2}^{2} v}{2}} e^{-m_{1} l p} h^{\prime}(t-v, l q) e^{-\frac{m_{2}^{2}(t-v)}{2}} e^{m_{2} l q} h^{\prime}(T-t, x) e^{-\frac{m_{2}^{2}(T-t)}{2}} \mathrm{~d} v \mathrm{~d} t \mathrm{~d} l \\
& =2 p e^{m_{1} x} \int_{0}^{\infty} \int_{0}^{T} \int_{0}^{t} h\left(v ; l p, m_{1}\right) h\left(t-v ; l q, m_{2}\right) e^{2 m_{2} l q} h\left(T-t ; x, m_{2}\right) e^{m_{2} x} \mathrm{~d} v \mathrm{~d} t \mathrm{~d} l
\end{aligned}
$$

Now we change the order of $v$ and $t$ in the triple integration:

$$
\begin{aligned}
\mathbb{P}_{T}(x) & =2 p e^{m_{1} x} \int_{0}^{\infty} \int_{0}^{T} \int_{v}^{T} h\left(v ; l p, m_{1}\right) h\left(t-v ; l q, m_{2}\right) e^{2 m_{2} l q} h\left(T-t ; x, m_{2}\right) e^{m_{2} x} \mathrm{~d} t \mathrm{~d} v \mathrm{~d} l \\
& =2 p e^{m_{1} x} \int_{0}^{\infty} \int_{0}^{T} h\left(v ; l p, m_{1}\right) e^{2 m_{2} l q} e^{m_{2} x} \int_{v}^{T} h\left(t-v ; l q, m_{2}\right) h\left(T-t ; x, m_{2}\right) \mathrm{d} t \mathrm{~d} v \mathrm{~d} l
\end{aligned}
$$

Changing variable $u=T-t$ we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
\mathbb{P}_{T}(x) & =2 p e^{m_{1} x} \int_{0}^{\infty} \int_{0}^{T} h\left(v ; l p, m_{1}\right) e^{2 m_{2} l q} e^{m_{2} x} \int_{0}^{T-v} h\left(T-v-u ; l q, m_{2}\right) h\left(u ; x, m_{2}\right) \mathrm{d} u \mathrm{~d} v \mathrm{~d} l \\
& =2 p e^{m_{1} x} \int_{0}^{\infty} \int_{0}^{T} h\left(v ; l p, m_{1}\right) e^{2 m_{2} l q} e^{m_{2} x} h\left(T-v ; l q+x, m_{2}\right) \mathrm{d} v \mathrm{~d} l \\
& =2 p e^{m_{1} x} \int_{0}^{\infty} \int_{0}^{T} h\left(v ; l p, m_{1}\right) h\left(T-v ; l q+x,-m_{2}\right) e^{-m_{2} x} \mathrm{~d} v \mathrm{~d} l \\
& =2 p e^{\left(m_{1}-m_{2}\right) x} \int_{0}^{\infty} \int_{0}^{T} h\left(v ; l p, m_{1}\right) h\left(T-v ; l q+x,-m_{2}\right) \mathrm{d} v \mathrm{~d} l
\end{aligned}
$$

which is not equal to probability density in Theorem (4).
for $x<0$ :

$$
\begin{aligned}
\mathbb{P}_{T}(x) & =\int_{0}^{\infty} \int_{0}^{T} \int_{v}^{T} \phi_{T}(t, v, x, l) \mathrm{d} t \mathrm{~d} v \mathrm{~d} l \\
& =\int_{0}^{\infty} \int_{0}^{T} \int_{v}^{T} 2 q h^{\prime}(v, l p) h^{\prime}(t-v, l q) h^{\prime}(T-t, x) e^{-\frac{m_{2}^{2} v}{2}-\frac{m_{2}^{2}(T-v)}{2}-l\left(m_{1} p-q m_{2}\right)+m_{2} x} \mathrm{~d} t \mathrm{~d} v \mathrm{~d} l \\
& =2 q \int_{0}^{\infty} \int_{0}^{T} \int_{v}^{T} h^{\prime}(v, l p) e^{-\frac{m_{2}^{2} v}{2}} e^{-m_{1} l p} h^{\prime}(t-v, l q) h^{\prime}(T-t, x) e^{-\frac{m_{2}^{2}(T-t+t-v)}{2}+m_{2} l q+m_{2} x} \mathrm{~d} t \mathrm{~d} v \mathrm{~d} l \\
& =2 q \int_{0}^{\infty} \int_{0}^{T} \int_{v}^{T} h^{\prime}(v, l p) e^{-\frac{m_{2}^{2} v}{2}} e^{-m_{1} l p} h^{\prime}(t-v, l q) e^{-\frac{m_{2}^{2}(t-v)}{2}} e^{m_{2} l q} h^{\prime}(T-t, x) e^{-\frac{m_{2}^{2}(T-t)}{2}} e^{m_{2} x} \mathrm{~d} t \mathrm{~d} v \mathrm{~d} l \\
& =2 q \int_{0}^{\infty} \int_{0}^{T} \int_{v}^{T} h\left(v ; l p, m_{1}\right) h\left(t-v ; l q, m_{2}\right) e^{2 m_{2} l q} h\left(T-t ; x, m_{2}\right) e^{2 m_{2} x} \mathrm{~d} t \mathrm{~d} v \mathrm{~d} l \\
& =2 q \int_{0}^{\infty} \int_{0}^{T} h\left(v ; l p, m_{1}\right) e^{2 m_{2} l q} \int_{v}^{T} h\left(t-v ; l q, m_{2}\right) h\left(T-t ;-x, m_{2}\right) \mathrm{d} t \mathrm{~d} v \mathrm{~d} l
\end{aligned}
$$

By Changing of variable $u=T-t$ :

$$
\begin{aligned}
\mathbb{P}_{T}(x) & =2 q \int_{0}^{\infty} \int_{0}^{T} h\left(v ; l p, m_{1}\right) e^{2 m_{2} l q} \int_{0}^{T-v} h\left(T-v-u ; l q, m_{2}\right) h\left(u ;-x, m_{2}\right) \mathrm{d} u \mathrm{~d} v \mathrm{~d} l \\
& =2 q \int_{0}^{\infty} \int_{0}^{T} h\left(v ; l p, m_{1}\right) e^{2 m_{2} l q} h\left(T-v ; l q-x, m_{2}\right) \mathrm{d} v \mathrm{~d} l \\
& =2 q \int_{0}^{\infty} \int_{0}^{T} h\left(v ; l p, m_{1}\right) e^{2 m_{2}(l q-x)} e^{2 m_{2} x} h\left(T-v ; l q-x, m_{2}\right) \mathrm{d} v \mathrm{~d} l \\
& =2 q e^{2 m_{2} x} \int_{0}^{\infty} \int_{0}^{T} h\left(v ; l p, m_{1}\right) h\left(T-v ; l q-x,-m_{2}\right) \mathrm{d} v \mathrm{~d} l
\end{aligned}
$$

which is equal to probability density in Theorem 4.

# Based on equation (2.4) in their paper 

Based on the same paper, the joint density of the refracted skew Brownian motion $\left(X_{T}\right)$, its last visit to the origin $(\tau)$, total occupation time $(U)$, and local times $\left(L_{T}^{(0)}(X)\right)$ is given by equation (2.4):

$$
\varphi_{T}(t, v, x, l)= \begin{cases}2 p h^{\prime}(u+t-T, l p) h^{\prime}(T-u, l q) h^{\prime}(T-t, x) e^{-\frac{m_{1}^{2} u}{2}-\frac{m_{2}^{2}(T-u)}{2}-l\left(m_{1} p-q m_{2}\right)+m_{1} x}, & x>0 \\ l>0, t \leq T, T-t \leq u \leq T, & \\ 2 q h^{\prime}(u, l p) h^{\prime}(t-u, l q) h^{\prime}(T-t, x) e^{-\frac{m_{1}^{2} u}{2}-\frac{m_{2}^{2}(T-u)}{2}-l\left(m_{1} p-q m_{2}\right)+m_{2} x}, & x<0\end{cases}
$$

Now, let's find the marginal distribution of $X_{T}$, for $x>0$ :

$$
\begin{aligned}
\mathbb{P}_{T}(x) & =\int_{0}^{\infty} \int_{0}^{T} \int_{T-t}^{T} \varphi_{T}(t, v, x, l) \mathrm{d} u \mathrm{~d} t \mathrm{~d} l \\
& =\int_{0}^{\infty} \int_{0}^{T} \int_{T-t}^{T} 2 p h^{\prime}(u+t-T, l p) h^{\prime}(T-u, l q) h^{\prime}(T-t, x) e^{-\frac{m_{1}^{2} u}{2}-\frac{m_{2}^{2}(T-u)}{2}-l\left(m_{1} p-q m_{2}\right)+m_{1} x} \mathrm{~d} u \mathrm{~d} t \mathrm{~d} l \\
& =2 p e^{m_{1} x} \int_{0}^{\infty} \int_{0}^{T} \int_{T-t}^{T} h^{\prime}(u+t-T, l p) h^{\prime}(T-u, l q) h^{\prime}(T-t, x) e^{-\frac{m_{1}^{2} u}{2}-\frac{m_{2}^{2}(T-u)}{2}-l\left(m_{1} p-q m_{2}\right)} \mathrm{d} u \mathrm{~d} t \mathrm{~d} l \\
& =2 p e^{m_{1} x} \int_{0}^{\infty} \int_{0}^{T} \int_{T-t}^{T} h^{\prime}(u+t-T, l p) e^{\frac{-m_{1}^{2}}{2}(u+t-T)} e^{-m_{1} l p} h^{\prime}(T-u, l q) e^{-\frac{m_{2}^{2}(T-u)}{2}+l q m_{2}} h^{\prime}(T-t, x) e^{-\frac{m_{1}^{2}(T-t)}{2}} \mathrm{~d} u \mathrm{~d} t \mathrm{~d} l \\
& =2 p e^{m_{1} x} \int_{0}^{\infty} \int_{0}^{T} \int_{T-t}^{T} h\left(u+t-T ; l p, m_{1}\right) h\left(T-u ; l q, m_{2}\right) e^{2 l q m_{2}} h^{\prime}\left(T-t ; x, m_{1}\right) e^{m_{1} x} \mathrm{~d} u \mathrm{~d} t \mathrm{~d} l
\end{aligned}
$$

Now we change the order of $u$ and $t$ in the triple integration:

$$
\mathbb{P}_{T}(x)=2 p e^{2 m_{1} x} \int_{0}^{\infty} \int_{0}^{T} \int_{T-u}^{T} h\left(u+t-T ; l p, m_{1}\right) h\left(T-u ; l q, m_{2}\right) e^{2 l q m_{2}} h^{\prime}\left(T-t ; x, m_{1}\right) \mathrm{d} t \mathrm{~d} u \mathrm{~d} l
$$

Using the change of variable $v=T-t$,

$$
\begin{aligned}
\mathbb{P}_{T}(x) & =2 p e^{2 m_{1} x} \int_{0}^{\infty} \int_{0}^{T} \int_{0}^{u} h\left(u-v ; l p, m_{1}\right) h\left(T-u ; l q, m_{2}\right) e^{2 l q m_{2}} h^{\prime}\left(v ; x, m_{1}\right) \mathrm{d} v \mathrm{~d} u \mathrm{~d} l \\
& =2 p e^{2 m_{1} x} \int_{0}^{\infty} \int_{0}^{T} h\left(T-u ; l q,-m_{2}\right) \int_{0}^{u} h\left(u-v ; l p, m_{1}\right) h^{\prime}\left(v ; x, m_{1}\right) \mathrm{d} v \mathrm{~d} u \mathrm{~d} l \\
& =2 p e^{2 m_{1} x} \int_{0}^{\infty} \int_{0}^{T} h\left(T-u ; l q,-m_{2}\right) h\left(u ; l p+x, m_{1}\right) \mathrm{d} u \mathrm{~d} l
\end{aligned}
$$

which is equal to probability density in Theorem (4).

Now, let's find the marginal distribution of $X_{T}$, for $x<0$ :

$$
\begin{aligned}
\mathbb{P}_{T}(x) & =\int_{0}^{\infty} \int_{0}^{T} \int_{u}^{T} \varphi_{T}(t, v, x, l) \mathrm{d} u \mathrm{~d} t \mathrm{~d} l \\
& =\int_{0}^{\infty} \int_{0}^{T} \int_{u}^{T} 2 q h^{\prime}(u, l p) h^{\prime}(t-u, l q) h^{\prime}(T-t, x) e^{-\frac{m_{1}^{2} u}{2}-\frac{m_{2}^{2}(T-u)}{2}-l\left(m_{1} p-q m_{2}\right)+m_{2} x} \mathrm{~d} t \mathrm{~d} u \mathrm{~d} l \\
& =2 q \int_{0}^{\infty} \int_{0}^{T} \int_{u}^{T} h^{\prime}(u, l p) e^{-\frac{m_{1}^{2} u}{2}-m_{1} l p} h^{\prime}(t-u, l q) e^{-\frac{m_{2}^{2}(t-u)}{2}+m_{2} l q} h^{\prime}(T-t, x) e^{-\frac{m_{2}^{2}(T-t)}{2}+m_{2} x} \mathrm{~d} t \mathrm{~d} u \mathrm{~d} l \\
& =2 q \int_{0}^{\infty} \int_{0}^{T} \int_{u}^{T} h\left(u ; l p, m_{1}\right) h\left(t-u ; l q, m_{2}\right) e^{2 m_{2} l q} h\left(T-t ; x, m_{2}\right) e^{2 m_{2} x} \mathrm{~d} t \mathrm{~d} u \mathrm{~d} l
\end{aligned}
$$

Using the change of variable $v=T-t$,

$$
\begin{aligned}
\mathbb{P}_{T}(x) & =2 q \int_{0}^{\infty} \int_{0}^{T} \int_{0}^{T-u} h\left(u ; l p, m_{1}\right) h\left(T-u-v ; l q, m_{2}\right) e^{2 m_{2} l q} h\left(v ; x, m_{2}\right) e^{2 m_{2} x} \mathrm{~d} v \mathrm{~d} u \mathrm{~d} l \\
& =2 q \int_{0}^{\infty} \int_{0}^{T} h\left(u ; l p, m_{1}\right) e^{2 m_{2} l q} \int_{0}^{T-u} h\left(T-u-v ; l q, m_{2}\right) h\left(v ;-x, m_{2}\right) \mathrm{d} v \mathrm{~d} u \mathrm{~d} l \\
& =2 q \int_{0}^{\infty} \int_{0}^{T} h\left(u ; l p, m_{1}\right) e^{2 m_{2} l q} h\left(T-u ; l q-x, m_{2}\right) \mathrm{d} u \mathrm{~d} l \\
& =2 q e^{2 m_{2} x} \int_{0}^{\infty} \int_{0}^{T} h\left(u ; l p, m_{1}\right) h\left(T-u ; l q-x, m_{2}\right) e^{2 m_{2} l q} e^{-2 m_{2} x} \mathrm{~d} u \mathrm{~d} l \\
& =2 q e^{2 m_{2} x} \int_{0}^{\infty} \int_{0}^{T} h\left(u ; l p, m_{1}\right) h\left(T-u ; l q-x,-m_{2}\right) \mathrm{d} u \mathrm{~d} l
\end{aligned}
$$

which is equal to probability density in Theorem (4).

abstract:
For refracted skew Brownian motion (skew Brownian motion with two-valued
drift), adopting a perturbation approach we find expressions of its potential
densities. As applications, we recover its transition density and study its
long-time asymptotic behaviors. In addition, we also compare with previous
results on transition densities for skew Brownian motions. We propose two
approaches for generating quasi-random samples by approximating the cumulative
distribution function and discuss their risk measurement application.
